Furthermore, upon the occurrence of certain events constituting a change of control, the Issuer may be required to make an offer to repurchase all of the relevant series of Notes at a redemption price equal to 101% of the

the principal amount thereof. See “Description of the Notes.”

In connection with any tender offers for any series of Notes, if holders of not less than 90% in aggregate principal amount of the applicable outstanding Notes of such series validly tender and do not withdraw such Notes in
such tender offer and the Issuer, or any third party making such a tender offer in lieu of the Issuer, purchases, all of such Notes validly tendered and not withdrawn by such holders, the Issuer or such third party will have the
right to redeem the Notes of such series that remain outstanding in whole, but not in part, following such purchase at a price equal to the price offered to each other holder of Notes of such series (excluding any early tender or
incentive fee) plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to, but excluding, the redemption date.
Concurrently with the closing of the Offering, the Initial Purchasers (as defined herein) will deposit the gross proceeds of the Offering into an escrow account in the name of the Issuer but controlled by the Escrow Agent (as
defined herein) (the “Escrow Account”) and pledged on a first-ranking basis in favor of the Trustee for the benefit of the holders of the Notes (the “Escrow Charge”). The release of the Escrowed Property (as defined herein)
will be subject to the satisfaction of certain conditions. If the Acquisition is not consummated on or prior to the Escrow Longstop Date (as defined herein) or upon occurrence of certain other events, the Notes will be subject to
a special mandatory redemption. The special mandatory redemption price of each series of Notes will be equal to 100% of the aggregate initial issue price of such series of Notes plus accrued and unpaid interest, and
additional amounts, if any, from the Issue Date to, but excluding the special mandatory redemption date. In the event that the consummation of the Acquisition is expected to occur on or about, and in any event, within three
business days of, the Issue Date, the gross proceeds of the Offering may be directly utilized by the Issuer to, inter alia, complete the Acquisition as described in the section “Use of Proceeds” without being subject to the
escrow arrangements described in this Offering Memorandum in which case, the escrow-related mechanics (but not the special mandatory redemption provisions) described in this Offering Memorandum shall be deemed
redundant. See “Description of the Notes —Escrow of Proceeds; Special Mandatory Redemption.”

The Notes will be senior obligations of the Issuer and will rank pari passu in right of payment with any existing and future indebtedness of the Issuer that is not expressly subordinated in right of payment to the Notes. On the
Issue Date, the Notes will not be guaranteed. Following the Acquisition Closing Date (as defined herein), the Issuer will use commercially reasonable efforts to cause the Target to guarantee the Notes (the “Upstream
**Guarantee”) within 120 days following the Acquisition Closing Date, subject to and in accordance with the Agreed Security Principles (as defined herein). Our ability to procure the Upstream Guarantee is subject to certain**
material legal and contractual limitations (including the completion of the Whitewash Procedure (as defined herein)), which may limit the value of such Guarantee or result in us not being able to provide it at all as described
under “Risks Related to the Notes, the Collateral and any Future Notes Guarantees—The Collateral, the Upstream Guarantee and any future guarantees or security of the Notes will be subject to certain limitations on
_enforcement and may be limited by applicable laws or subject to certain defenses that may limit their validity and enforceability.” In addition, following the Acquisition Closing Date, the Issuer will use commercially_
reasonable efforts to complete the Post-Closing Reorganization (as defined herein) as a result of which the Issuer will merge into the Target under a reverse merger (with the Target being the surviving entity) within 18 months
following the Acquisition Closing Date, subject to the Agreed Security Principles. The Post-Closing Reorganization is subject to certain conditions, including legal and regulatory approvals and may not be completed. See
“Risks Related to the Group’s Capital Structure— _We may be unable to complete the Post-Closing Reorganization within the anticipated timeframe, or at all.” Prior to the earlier of the implementation of the Post-Closing_
Reorganization and the Guarantee of the Notes by the Target, the Notes will be structurally subordinated to any existing or future obligations of the Target, including the Existing Notes and the Revolving Credit Facility.

On the Issue Date, the Notes will be secured by the Escrow Charge. On or about the Acquisition Closing Date, the Issuer, HoldCo (as defined herein) and the Trustee will accede to the Intercreditor Agreement. Subject to the
Agreed Security Principles and the Intercreditor Agreement, (a) on or about the Acquisition Closing Date, the Notes will be secured by the Issuer Share Pledge (as defined herein); and (b) within 10 Business Days following
the Acquisition Closing Date, the Notes will be secured by the Target Share Pledge (as defined herein). Under the terms of the Intercreditor Agreement (as defined herein), in the event of enforcement of the Collateral, the
holders of the Notes will receive proceeds from such Collateral only after certain parties, including the lenders under the Revolving Credit Facility (as defined herein) and counterparties to certain hedging agreements have
been repaid in full. In addition, any future Guarantees and the security interests in the Collateral may be released under certain circumstances and any future Guarantees and the Collateral will be subject to legal and
contractual limitations. See “Risk Factors,” “Description of the Notes” and “Limitations on Validity and Enforceability of any Notes Guarantees and the Collateral and Certain Insolvency Law Considerations.”

Subject to and as set forth in “Description of the Notes—Withholding Taxes,” the Issuer will not be liable to pay any additional amounts to holders of the relevant series of Notes in relation to any withholding or deduction
required pursuant to Italian Legislative Decree No. 239 of April 1, 1996 (as the same may be amended or supplemented from time to time) where the Notes are held by a person resident in a country that is not listed in the
White List (as defined below) and otherwise in the circumstances as described in “Description of the Notes—Withholding Taxes.”

There is currently no public market for the Notes. Application will be made for the Notes to be listed on the Official List of the Luxembourg Stock Exchange and admitted to trading on the Euro MTF Market thereof. There is

**Use of Non-GAAP Financial Measures**

Certain parts of this Offering Memorandum contain alternative performance measures as defined by the “ESMA
Guidelines on Alternative Performance Measures” issued by ESMA on October 5, 2015 (“APMs”) which are
non-GAAP measures and ratios and have thereof not been subject to audit or review. Such non-GAAP measures
include: “EBITDA,” “EBITDA Margin,” “Adjusted EBITDA,” “Adjusted EBITDA margin,” “EBIT,”
“EBIT Margin,” “Adjusted EBIT,” “Adjusted EBIT margin,” “Net Working Capital,” “Net Invested
**Capital,” “Net Financial Indebtedness,” “Capex,” “Operating Free Cash Flow,” “Adjusted Operating**
**Free Cash Flow,” “Cash Conversion,” “Adjusted Cash Conversion,”** “Annualized run-rate Adjusted
**EBITDA.”**

We have included the non-GAAP Measures because we believe that such measures enable us to assess the
performance of our business and provide investors with additional information to enhance understanding of our
results. These non-GAAP Measures are based on a number of complex assumptions and have not been subject
to audit or review. While we believe our assumptions and the data underlying our estimates and key
performance indicators are reasonable, there are inherent challenges in measuring such information. The
conditions supporting our assumptions or estimates may change at any time, and as a result, the assumptions and
estimates upon which the non-GAAP Measures are based may not be correct. For these reasons, non-GAAP
Measures used should not be considered as an alternative to profit (loss), revenue or any other performance
measure derived in accordance with Italian GAAP, IFRS or any other accounting principles nor to net cash
provided by operating activities as a measure of liquidity. Non-GAAP Measures have limitations as analytical
tools over and above the limitations of any accounting principles performance measures and should not be
considered in isolation or as substitutes for analysis of the Group’s results as reported under Italian GAAP. Such
non-GAAP measures may include or exclude amounts that are included or excluded, as applicable, in the
calculation of the most directly comparable measures in accordance with Italian GAAP. Their usefulness is
therefore subject to limitations, which are described below. In particular, other companies in the industry may
define the non-GAAP measures used herein, differently, which may make it difficult to compare the
performance of these entities to our performance based on similarly named measures. These measures may be
used by different companies for different purposes and are often calculated in ways that reflect the
circumstances of those companies. In addition, the exclusion of certain items from non-GAAP measures does


-----

not imply that these items are necessarily non- recurring. From time to time, we may exclude additional items if
we believe doing so would result in a more transparent and comparable disclosure.

You should exercise caution in comparing this data to similar measures used by other companies. The
information presented has not been prepared in accordance with Italian GAAP, IFRS or any other accounting
standards. In addition, the presentation of these measures is not intended to and does not comply with the
reporting requirements of the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission (the “SEC”) and will not be subject to
review by the SEC; compliance with its requirements would require us to make changes to the presentation of
this information.

These measures are not measurements of performance under Italian GAAP, IFRS or any other accounting
principles and you should not consider them as an alternative to profit/(loss) before taxes or profit/(loss) from
continuing operations determined in accordance with Italian GAAP, IFRS or any other accounting principles, or,
as the case may be, or to cash flows from/(used in) operating activities, cash used in investing activities or cash
flow from/(used in) financing activities. These measures are not indicative of our historical operating results, nor
are they meant to be predictive of future results. Therefore, investors should not place undue reliance on this
data.

Non-GAAP Measures should be considered in conjunction with the Consolidated Financial Statements prepared
in accordance with Italian GAAP. Although certain of these measures have been extracted or derived from the
Consolidated Financial Statements, this data has not been audited or reviewed.

Each of the non-GAAP measures presented in this Offering Memorandum are defined below. For further
information, including definitions and reconciliations of the non-GAAP measures prepared on a management
basis to the most directly comparable financial measures prepared in accordance with Italian GAAP, see
“Summary — Summary Financial and Other Information — Summary Other Financial and Operating Data.”

**_EBITDA and EBITDA Margin_**

We define EBITDA as the sum of profit after tax, income taxes, value adjustments of financial assets, financial
income and expenses, foreign exchange gains and losses and amortization and depreciation.

We present EBITDA because we believe it is a meaningful measure to evaluate the Group’s operating
performance on a consistent basis over time. EBITDA makes the underlying performance of our business more
visible by factoring out depreciation and amortization, interest income and interest expenses and income tax
expenses. This measure is also commonly used by investors, analysts and rating agencies to assess performance.

We define EBITDA Margin as the ratio between EBITDA and the value of production and is used by the Group
as a supplemental measure of operating performance.

**_Adjusted EBITDA and Adjusted EBITDA Margin_**

We define Adjusted EBITDA as EBITDA adjusted for write-offs and non-recurring items.

We present Adjusted EBITDA because it excludes items that we do not believe are indicative of the Group’s
ongoing operating performance and allows us to view operating trends, perform analytical comparisons and
benchmark performance between periods. We believe that adjusting for these items that are not directly related
to our operational performance increases comparability and enables a better understanding of the underlying
performance of the Group.

We define Adjusted EBITDA margin as the ratio between Adjusted EBITDA and the value of production.

**_EBIT and EBIT Margin_**

We define EBIT as the sum of profit after tax, income taxes, value adjustments of financial assets, financial
income and expenses, foreign exchange gains and losses.

We present EBIT because we believe it is a meaningful measure to evaluate the Group’s operating performance
on a consistent basis over time. EBIT makes the underlying performance of our business more visible by


-----

factoring out interest income and interest expenses and income tax expenses. This measure is also commonly
used by investors, analysts and rating agencies to assess performance.

We define EBIT Margin as the ratio between EBIT and the value of production, and is used by the Group as a
supplemental measure of operating performance.

**_Adjusted EBIT and Adjusted EBIT Margin_**

We define Adjusted EBIT as EBIT adjusted for non-recurring items and goodwill amortization related to the
initial purchase price allocation.

We define Adjusted EBIT margin as the ratio between Adjusted EBIT and the value of production.

**_Net Working Capital_**

We define Net Working Capital as the sum of inventories, trade receivables, trade payables, and other current
and non current liabilities, including deferred revenue.

We present Net Working Capital because we believe it is a meaningful measure to evaluate our operating
liquidity.

**_Net Invested Capital_**

We define Net Invested Capital as the sum of tangible and intangible assets, net working capital, other non
current assets and liabilities, and investments.

We present Net Invested Capital because we believe it is a meaningful measure to evaluate our investments and
liquidity.

**_Net Financial Indebtedness_**

We define Net Financial Indebtedness as the sum of liquidity and financial indebtedness (current and noncurrent).

**_Capex_**

We define Capex as the sum of cash outflow from investing in property, plant and equipment and in intangible
assets.

**_Operating Free Cash Flow_**

We define Operating Free Cash Flow as EBITDA less Capex and Change in Net Working Capital (which
reflects the change in inventories, trade receivables and trade payables and net of accruals and deferrals during
the period).

**_Adjusted Operating Free Cash Flow_**

We define Adjusted Operating Free Cash Flow as Adjusted EBITDA less Capex and Change in Net Working
Capital.

**_Cash Conversion_**

We define Cash Conversion as the ratio of (i) the Operating Free Cash Flow; and (ii) EBITDA.

**_Adjusted Cash Conversion_**

We define Adjusted Cash Conversion as the ratio of (i) the Adjusted Operating Free Cash Flow; and (ii)
Adjusted EBITDA.

**Overview**

**_General_**

Established in 2006, Multiversity is the leading university in the Italian online higher education market with
approximately 151,000 undergraduate enrolled students (and approximately 206,000 enrolled students in total)
for the 2022/2023 academic year. Based on the number of university students enrolled for the 2022/2023
academic year, the company has an estimated market share in the Italian online academic education of 57%, an
estimated market share in the Italian academic education (across both physical and online universities) of 8%[1]
and a student satisfaction rate of 98%[2]. Multiversity also has a leading role in the foundation of UNITED (the
first association of Italian online universities). It operates several education assets, and in particular:

  - Online universities: Multiversity operates three fully licensed private online universities in Italy with
MIUR accreditations: Università Telematica Pegaso S.r.l. (“Pegaso”), Universitas Mercatorum
(“Mercatorum”) and Università Telematica San Raffaele Roma S.r.l. (“San Raffaele”). It provides a
student centric proposition with a wide array of undergraduate and post graduate courses to
approximately 206,000 students for the 2022/2023 academic year and is supported by a strong
professor base (10 Multiversity professors have been included in the “Top Scientists – World Top 2%”
ranking from Stanford University). Degrees awarded at the end of academic courses have the same
legal value as degrees issued by traditional universities. 97.4% of Multiversity’s revenue for the year
ended December 31, 2023 was generated by the university segment.

  - Non-academic courses and certifications: Multiversity has also expanded into a complementary nonuniversity education segment, mainly focusing on: (i) B2B and B2C executive education through Sole
24 Ore Formazione S.p.A. (“Sole 24 Ore Formazione”), (ii) digital skills through Aulab S.r.l.
(“Aulab”), a coding factory, which delivers short term courses for software developers, and (iii) a
certification entity, Certipass S.r.l. (“Certipass”). 2.3% of Multiversity’s revenue for the year ended
December 31, 2023 was generated by the non-academic education segment.

  - Other assets: Multiversity also operates a number of academies offering courses on specific subjects
(e.g. communication, marketing and law) as well as other assets (e.g. Principe di Napoli, which
provides gastronomy and tourism higher education, or Benecon, a research center promoted by the
Campania Region). 0.3% of Multiversity’s revenues for the year ended December 31, 2023 were
generated by the other assets segment.

Multiversity delivers its services through a proprietary online platform that produces its e-learning content,
which is developed in-house. In addition, Multiversity is also a pioneer in the use of artificial intelligence in
education, in particular for marketing purposes and for the development of new use cases (such as its Tutor
Chatbot and Exam Generator applications).

Pegaso is Multiversity’s largest university. Approximately 140,000 students were enrolled in Pegaso’s online
courses for the 2022/2023 academic year. Pegaso offers a range of both undergraduate and postgraduate courses,
and in particular eight undergraduate bachelor’s degrees, five specialist master’s degrees, one single cycle fiveyear degree and 158 courses, including postgraduate master’s courses and higher education and specialization
courses for professionals and high school graduates. Pegaso also offers individual certifications and gives
students the possibility to undertake single examinations for each course module upon payment of a fee without
having to complete the full course.

Multiversity’s second key institution, Mercatorum, is 66.67% owned by Multiversity, with the remaining
33.33% stake held by Unioncamere, the Italian Union of Chambers of Commerce, Industry, Crafts and
Agriculture, which is the public body that unifies and institutionally represents the Italian system of chambers of
commerce. Approximately 53,000 students were enrolled in Mercatorum for the 2022/2023 academic year.
Mercatorum’s core offering consists of 14 undergraduate bachelor’s degrees, five specialist master’s degrees,
five Ph.D. programs and 121 courses, including postgraduate master’s courses and higher education and
specialization courses for professionals and high school graduates.

Multiversity’s third primary institution in terms of revenue, San Raffaele, became part of the Group in 2022, and
it is wholly owned by Multiversity. San Raffaele delivers courses mainly related to biomedical and healthcare
sciences, and it ranks first in research quality among digital universities and fifth among the entire national
university system.[3] Approximately 13,000 students were enrolled in San Raffaele for the 2022/2023 academic
year, and its core offering currently consists of four undergraduate bachelor’s degrees, three specialist master’s
degrees, six Ph.D. programs and 39 postgraduate master’s courses.

**_Non-academic courses and certifications_**

In relation to the non-university education segment, Multiversity operates Sole 24 Ore Formazione in
partnership with Il Sole 24 Ore S.p.A. (with Multiversity holding a majority stake of 85%) to deliver B2B and
B2C executive master's courses to professionals and young graduates. As part of the B2B offerings, Multiversity
also offers compulsory courses, soft skills, industry and managerial training to corporates. These courses can be
offered as off-the shelf, co-designed or fully customized. The B2B courses can vary in length, while the B2C
courses typically last one to six months. The new partnership benefits from a top level academic and scientific
training offer, thanks to the support of the universities that are part of the Group as well as the support and the
strong brand recognition of the Il Sole 24 Ore group (owning the 15% of Sole 24 Ore Formazione), one of the
leading finance newspapers in Italy, which provides content to readers, professionals, businesses, and
institutions on topics of economics, finance, and management. Additionally, Multiversity owns 60.61% of
Aulab, a player in the digital training sector for developers with a high placement rate of its students thanks to
an effective training model for coding and IT education, an efficient placement platform and partnerships with
top companies. This training model requires no pre-requisites and typically lasts from three to six months. In
addition to training, Aulab also designs and develops websites, IT platforms and software applications. The nonuniversity segment also includes Certipass, a provider of international EIPASS certifications for digital
competences and IT skills.

**_Academies and other assets_**

The Group also includes a number of academies established through collaboration agreements between Pegaso,
Mercatorum and San Raffaele and their respective commercial partners, covering a wide range of specialist
subjects such as marketing, communications and media and teaching. Other assets include Principe di Napoli
S.a.r.l. (“Principe di Napoli”), established in February 2019 by Pegaso in partnership with Mercatorum
(holding 90% and 10% stakes, respectively) as a center for higher education and specialization in the sectors of
gastronomy and tourism. Apart from the Postgraduate School in Legal Professions (as further described below),
Principe di Napoli is one of the few institution within Multiversity to hold on premise courses. Additionally, in
December 2023, the Group acquired a minority stake in Materias S.r.l., an incubator of scientific research
activities engaged in identifying innovative ideas in the field of advanced materials, primarily generated from
the academic sector.

Multiversity also operates a publishing entity and companies dedicated to research, which are mostly ancillary
and in support of the three universities. Almost the entirety of its operations are located in Italy, with some
limited operations in Malta (Pegaso International). It also has collaboration agreements with several partners in

Italy for the development and delivery of specialized courses in a multitude of subjects, made available through
its three universities.

In order to support their online offering, Multiversity’s institutions have an extensive network of approximately
1,000[4] e-learning center points (the “ELCPs”) as of December 31, 2023. The ELCPs provide information to
prospective and current students about the various institutions and serve as orientation centers for new students
throughout the entire duration of the course they undertake. The ELCP Points performed orientation activities
for approximately 61% of Multiversity’s institution’s new students as of December 31, 2023; however, the
relevant institution retains the direct relationship with student as it manages the enrollment process and tuition
fee payments directly with the student[5]. As regards the ELCP Points across Certipass, these purchase EIPASS
cards from Certipass and on-sell them to customers who wish to obtain an EIPASS certification. All ELCPs are
managed by external third parties that have entered into specific accreditation agreements with Pegaso,
Mercatorum, San Raffaele or Certipass (in some cases, more than one institution has entered into an
accreditation agreement with the same ELCP). See “Material Contracts—Accreditation agreements for ELCPs”
below.

**_Financial Performance_**

Multiversity’s revenues for the financial year ended December 31, 2023 amounted to €419.9 million, as
compared to €332.0 million for the prior financial year ended December 31, 2022 (an increase of 26.5%).
Enrolled undergraduate students at Pegaso, Mercatorum and San Raffaele increased by approximately 28% in
the 2022/2023 academic year with respect to the 2021/2022 academic year.

In addition, Adjusted EBITDA generated for the year ended December 31, 2023 was €247.2 million as
compared to €200.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2022 (an increase of 23.6%). Adjusted EBITDA
margin for the year ended December 31, 2023 was 58.9%, as compared to 60.2% for the year ended December
31, 2022.

Furthermore, Adjusted Operating Free Cash Flow generated for the year ended December 31, 2023 was €226.0
million, as compared to €157.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2022 (an increase of 43%). Adjusted
Cash Conversion for the year ended December 31, 2023 was 91%, as compared to 79% for the year ended
December 31, 2022 (an increase of 12%).

**_Business Model_**

Multiversity’s business model is based on a student-centric offering of a flexible learning experience and access
to teaching content through its proprietary and technologically advanced e-learning platform. Multiversity’s
universities address specific unmet demand in the market for a flexible path to an undergraduate degree, whilst
catering to specific professions for postgraduate continuous learning.

Revenues are mainly driven by tuition fees paid by students, which contributed to 75%[6] of Multiversity’s
revenues. Almost the entirety of tuition fees is self-funded by students, with less than 1% paid through
scholarships. The levels of tuition fees in turn depend on the number of students, the nature or class of degree
undertaken, the year of enrollment, the type of course and the student’s selected enrollment channel, amongst
other factors. Undergraduate degrees, which are multi-year courses (three-year bachelor’s degree plus a twoyear specialist master’s degree, or a single-cycle five-year degree), are a recurring multi-year revenue stream for
the term of the program (consisting of both the tuition fees and any other ancillary fees), which has an average
course length of approximately 2.4 years. Approximately 30% of Multiversity's graduates who have completed
three-year undergraduate degree courses wish to continue their education and apply to enroll in two-year
specialist master’s degree and master’s degree courses with the same institution.

On the other hand, one-year postgraduate courses (i.e. second level master’s which may be undertaken by
students who have already completed a three year undergraduate bachelor’s degree plus a two year specialist
master’s degree or a single-cycle five year degree), together with higher education courses and specialization
courses, provide a one-off tuition fee payment per student, accounting for 6% of Multiversity’s revenues for the

The other assets segment (which include Principe di Napoli, Benecon and other smaller companies) accounted
for 0.3% of Multiversity’s revenues for the year ended December 31, 2023.

With respect to student orientation, around 61% of new students as of December 31, 2023 (contributing to 62%
of commercial revenues for the 2022/2023 academic year) across Pegaso, Mercatorum and San Raffaele partook
in orientation activities at the approximately 1,000 ELCPs that make up Multiversity’s national network.
Approximately 39% of students as of December 31, 2023 (contributing to 38% of commercial revenues for the
2022/2023 academic year) were reached through traditional marketing methods, e.g. billboards and TV
advertising campaigns on both private and public Italian channels, as well as through its extensive online
presence on social media and online advertising, thereby gaining access to the widest possible audience and
delivery tangible results, with an increase in new leads of 50% in 2023 compared to 2022. Multiversity has
established a nation-wide presence, with approximately 100 exam venues located in prestigious and historical
buildings, along with a strong online social community and proprietary technology platforms for online classes,
exams and tutoring.

Multiversity’s growth strategy is predominantly based on expanding volumes by increasing market penetration
within the population, whilst selectively increasing its course offering, its brand awareness, digital marketing
practices and _ad hoc_ orientation services to prospective students as well as by entering into commercial
agreements and partnerships.

Additionally, revenues are driven by increases in our tuition fees taking into account inflation and other
commercial considerations. For example, Multiversity increased its undergraduate tuition fees for newly
enrolling students by approximately 8% on average for the 2022/2023 academic year, as compared to the prior
academic year. See further “—Competitive Strengths” and “—Business Strategy” below.

The main objective underpinning Multiversity’s business strategy is to consolidate its market position and
strengthen its position as the leading entirely online education group in the Italian market, employing both
Business-to-Consumer and Business-to-Business marketing strategies in order to target an ever-wider audience
of students. See further “—Competitive Strengths” and “—Business Strategy” below.

**Competitive Strengths**

**_Multiversity operates in the sizeable Italian higher education market which is highly attractive due to its_**
**_structurally low graduate penetration, providing online universities an opportunity to fill the education_**
**_deficit_**

Multiversity benefits from operating in the sizeable Italian higher education market (1.9 million undergraduate
students in Italy across online and traditional universities for the 2022/2023 academic year compared to 1.8
million undergraduate students for the 2020/2021 academic year)[7], where graduate penetration lags behind other
European countries. University graduate penetration[8] in Italy stood at only 29% in 2020 (increasing from 25%
in 2015), compared to 44% on average for the EU, 56% for the U.K., 49% for France, 47% for Spain and 35%
for Germany for the same period.[9] This low penetration is due to a number of structural factors in Italy
described further below, the combination of which allows online universities such as Multiversity to fill the
education deficit.
Accessibility to physical universities in Italy remains challenging due to a number of factors, including (i) a high
geographic dispersion of the population in Italy when compared to other major European countries, with 52% of
Italians living in non-metropolitan areas[10] (compared to an average of 29% for Spain, the U.K., France and

has supported its deleveraging as illustrated below:

Multiversity’s organic growth has largely been driven by undergraduate enrollment. New undergraduate
enrollments have continued to grow over the years, increasing from around 50,000 in the 2017/2018 academic
year to around 151,000 in the 2022/2023 academic year. Undergraduate enrollment tends to have a longer
duration compared to graduate enrollment, with a strong conversion rate (40% of graduates from 3-year degree
programs apply for 1- or 2-year master’s degrees). These dynamics together with a low churn rate are of
particular relevance given that approximately 90% of the Group’s revenues for the year ended December 31,
2023 were generated from undergraduate programs[39], thus allowing strong visibility on future top-line
evolution.

Approximately 63% of Multiversity’s revenues for the financial year ended December 31, 2023 were already
secured as of January 1, 2023, primarily due to new enrollments for the 2022/2023 academic year between
August 2022 and December 2022 and to existing students’ enrollments for the 2022/2023 academic year,
while approximately 37% of revenues for the same period were derived from new students enrolled from
January 1, 2023.

access at their own time); an engaging user experience delivered through a proprietary and differentiated
cutting-edge technology platform, complete with a personalized student dashboard and virtual support; strong
brand recognition; a capillary network of physical ECLPs and exam centers; and attractive pricing.

Additionally, in line with the 2030 Agenda for the Sustainable Development Goals, we remain committed to
delivering an inclusive and accessible education, promoting opportunities of continuous learning for everyone,
and facilitating access to job opportunities for Multiversity students.

**_Continue to invest in academic quality and research, improving the student learning experience along with_**
**_facilitating effective placement into the job market_**

The breadth of Multiversity’s offering is one of the factors behind its success. Multiversity’s commitment to the
continuing investment in and improving of academic quality and research represents a core priority of our
strategy. We intend to continue growing Multiversity’s base of professors and focus on attracting highly
respectable professors with strong academic backgrounds, high publication rates and high rankings within their
respective fields.

Additionally, the level and quality of Multiversity’s educational offering is continuously monitored through a
comprehensive quantitative framework through which we track over 25 KPIs, which are actively monitored to
ensure the effectiveness of Multiversity’s educational offering and student placement. The framework operates
in three-steps: (i) first, we analyze an inbound student’s profile using demographic and education background
data; (ii) second, we measure the effectiveness of the delivery of Multiversity’s in-classroom and out-ofclassroom educational offering by tracking faculty excellence (such as publications, citations and research) and
learning outcome metrics (such as graduation, re-enrollment, churn rate and satisfaction); and (iii) lastly, we
measure post-degree placement performance, including employment rates and yearly salaries. This holistic
framework is critical to the ongoing development of Multiversity’s educational offering and supporting the
delivery of educational outcomes and high satisfaction to Multiversity students.

A number of further opportunities to enhance the overall student learning experience are generated by
developments in AI. Multiversity has already launched certain AI tools and services, including a Tutor Chatbot,
and will remain committed to innovation and investment through AI in augmentation of curriculum
development, compliance with standards, automatization of support services and other areas.

Beyond investments in academia, we believe Multiversity has the ability to further leverage its cutting-edge
technological platform to deliver educational content in a streamlined, intuitive and efficient manner within and
beyond its core education segments. Multiversity’s technological platform, which is supported by an internal IT
team with full back- and front-end capabilities, is proprietary and scalable. All of Multiversity’s library content,
consisting of over 30,000 hours of video across 40 undergraduate courses and 300 other courses including postgraduate and master’s courses, is produced in-house with a 1-6 month time-to-market, from designing a course
to making it available to students.

**_Maximize operating and financial performance_**

We continuously monitor and evaluate Multiversity’s operational performance to identify opportunities for
enhancement and to capitalize on embedded growth.

Multiversity continues to place significant emphasis on managing its costs efficiently, benefiting from higher
operating leverage and maintaining operational flexibility. This efficient production capability, together with
Multiversity’s current and relevant content library and proprietary platform, support Multiversity’s scalable
business model and sustained organic growth. We believe that Multiversity’s strong growth, combined with its
limited capital expenditure requirements, high cash conversion capabilities, and strong profitability margins,
will continue to generate significant cash flows to enable operational deleveraging.

We also seek to continue to generate tuition fee growth above cost inflation. Multiversity’s value proposition is
accessible at an affordable price, as Multiversity’s average tuition fee of €2,000 for the 2023/2024 academic
year is below both the average of Multiversity’s competitors and the average price students are prepared to pay
for online undergraduate university education. When combined with growing demand for online education,
Multiversity’s strong brand awareness and reputation provide us with the opportunity to continue to grow our
revenues organically while sustaining our margins.


-----

**_Pursue opportunities to grow selectively beyond Multiversity’s core undergraduate education segments and_**
**_online delivery model, leveraging the Group’s existing capabilities and integration track-record_**

We will continue to assess and pursue opportunities to grow beyond the core university segment by leveraging
Multiversity’s brand and capabilities, as well as through Multiversity’s existing non-university education
platform (including the provision of B2B/B2C executive education through the Sole 24 ORE Formazione
partnership and Multiversity’s Aulab coding factory) and selectively pursuing growth opportunities to further
broaden the reach of Multiversity’s business model.

In particular, we have identified three strategic initiatives for potential international expansion:

  - **Bolt-on acquisitions: Multiversity considers select opportunities for expansion through bolt-on**
acquisitions on an opportunistic basis, such as acquiring physical or online universities. Over recent
years, Multiversity has demonstrated its M&A capabilities with a successful execution track-record and
established processes for the efficient integration of acquired companies within the Group.

  - **Organic growth and partnerships: Multiversity has identified opportunities to expand into select**
Mediterranean countries, to leverage the Pegaso International brand and to establish partnerships with
local universities to offer an EU-recognized education in countries with a high propensity of emigration
to Italy and other countries in the European Mediterranean region, contributing to faster organic
expansion.

  - **Digital partnerships: Given its proprietary technological platform, we believe that Multiversity has**
the opportunity to form digital partnerships with education providers in developing countries to offer
technical support and online platforms, marketing strategy and other services to deliver university
content locally.

Within Italy, Multiversity's growth strategy will be focused on (i) consolidation of its university business
through the opportunistic acquisition of digital universities and the pursuit of physical opportunities, while
seeking to move towards a hybrid model and (ii) the expansion of its non-university offering synergistically,
through which it aims to strengthen its value proposition, widen its course offering and increase its presence in
the B2C/B2B continuous learning space.

**Recent Developments**

**_Trading Update_**

Based on unaudited preliminary management accounts, the Group’s estimated revenues[41] for the last twelve
months ended February 29, 2024 amounted to €431.4 million, which represented an increase of 25.3% from
€344.2 million for the last twelve months ended February 28, 2023. These results were driven by the increase of
new enrollments for the period and undergraduate students enrolled during previous academic years, together
with the effects of the acquisition of San Raffaele. The estimated Adjusted EBITDA margin for the last twelve

**Principal Shareholders**

**_CVC_**

CVC is a leading private equity and investment advisory firm. Founded in 1981, CVC today has a network of 29
offices in five continents: 20 across the EMEA region and the Americas and nine in the Asia-Pacific region. As
of December 31, 2023, CVC has secured commitments of over €172 billion from over 500 investors from across
the world. In total, CVC’s private equity platform currently manages approximately €186 billion of assets.

**Information about the Issuer**

The Issuer is a joint stock company (società per azioni) established under the laws of the Republic of Italy and
is registered with the Companies’ Registry (Registro delle Imprese) of Milano, Monza, Brianza, Lodi under No.
13469160967. The registered office of the Issuer is located at Via del Vecchio Politecnico n.9, 20121 Milano,
Italy.

**The Transactions**

The transactions consist of the Acquisition and the Financing each as further described below (collectively, the
“Transactions”).

**_The Acquisition_**

On March 28, 2024, the Issuer entered into an acquisition agreement (the “Acquisition Agreement”) with
Paganini Investment S.à r.l (the “Seller”), relating to the sale and purchase of the entire issued share capital of
the Target held by the Seller (the “Acquisition”). The Acquisition is being effected in connection with the
indirect transfer of the Target by the fund known as “CVC Capital Partners VII Limited” (“CVC VII”) and
certain minority shareholders to CVC Capital Partners Pachelbel (A) SCSp (the “CV”) and the fund known as
“CVC Capital Partners VIII Limited” (“CVC VIII”), which will invest indirectly in the Issuer through an SCARAIF to be incorporated in due course, on arm’s length terms. As part of the proposed Acquisition, limited
partners in CVC VII will have the opportunity to make a commitment to the CV in an amount equal to up to
100% of the net cash distribution received by them from CVC VII as a result of the proposed Acquisition.
Investors in the CV are expected to include certain limited partners of CVC VII who make a commitment to the
CV (as described above) as well as certain new investors. In addition, certain co-investors, including certain
members of the management of the Target who currently hold a minority shareholding in the Seller, are
expected to reinvest in Holdco, an indirect holding company of the Issuer.

As a consequence of the transactions contemplated by the Acquisition Agreement, certain options in respect of
shares in the capital of the Target shall become exercisable pursuant to the Target’s stock option plan (such
shares to be issued by the Target upon exercise of the options being the “SOP Shares”). Such SOP Shares
called are expected to be purchased by the Issuer pursuant to a minority sale and purchase agreement to be
entered into on the Acquisition Closing Date (the “SOP SPA”). Completion under the SOP SPA will occur
substantially simultaneously with completion of the Acquisition such that, after completion of both the
Acquisition and the SOP SPA, the Issuer will hold the entire issued share capital in the Target.

The consummation of the Acquisition is subject to customary conditions. Upon consummation of the
Acquisition, CV and CVC VIII will indirectly acquire approximately 92% of the ownership interests in the
Group, with the remaining 8% being indirectly held by certain minority co-investors, including members of the
Target’s management (pursuant to a reinvestment in Holdco of the distribution received by them as a result of
the proposed Acquisition).

**_The Financing_**

The financing for the Acquisition consists of the Notes offered hereby, an equity contribution to be made by CV
and CVC VIII and certain co-investors, including certain members of the management of the Target who


-----

currently hold a minority shareholding in the Seller (pursuant to a reinvestment in Holdco as described above)
(together, the “Equity Contribution”).

In addition, on or about the Issue Date, certain lenders will make available to the Target, a new revolving credit
facility under the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement in an aggregate principal amount of up to €200.0 million
(“Revolving Credit Facility”), effective from the Acquisition Closing Date. The Revolving Credit Facility will
refinance the Existing Revolving Credit Facility, which will be cancelled in connection therewith. The Existing
Notes and certain other financial indebtedness of the Target are expected to remain outstanding, on an as
adjusted basis after giving pro forma effect to the Transactions as set out under “Capitalization.”

The foregoing financing arrangements, together with the application of proceeds thereof as set out under “Use of
_Proceeds,” are referred to herein as the “Financing.”_

**Post-Closing Reorganization**

Following the consummation of the Acquisition, the Issuer will use commercially reasonable efforts to complete
the Post-Closing Reorganization (as defined herein) as a result of which the Issuer will merge into the Target
under a reverse merger (with the Target being the surviving entity) within 18 months following the Acquisition
Closing Date, subject to the Agreed Security Principles. The Post-Closing Reorganization is subject to certain
conditions, including legal and regulatory approvals and may not be completed. See also “Risks Related to the
_Group’s Capital Structure—We may be unable to complete the Post-Closing Reorganization within the_
_anticipated timeframe, or at all.”_

**Escrow Arrangements**

Pending consummation of the Acquisition, the Initial Purchasers will, concurrently with the closing of the
Offering on the Issue Date, deposit the gross proceeds of the Offering into the Escrow Account in the name of
the Issuer but controlled by the Escrow Agent, and pledged on a first-ranking basis in favor of the Trustee for
the benefit of the holders of the Notes.

The release of the Escrowed Property will be subject to the satisfaction of certain conditions, including the
consummation of the Acquisition on or about, and in any event within three business days, following the date of
release of the Escrowed Property. If the Acquisition is not consummated on or prior to the Escrow Longstop
Date, the Notes will be subject to a special mandatory redemption. The special mandatory redemption price of
each series of Notes will be equal to 100% of the aggregate initial issue price of such series of Notes plus
accrued and unpaid interest, and additional amounts, if any, from the Issue Date to the special mandatory
redemption date. See “Description of the Notes—Escrow of Proceeds; Special Mandatory Redemption.” In the
event that the consummation of the Acquisition is expected to occur on or about, and in any event, within three
business days of, the Issue Date, the gross proceeds of the Offering may be directly utilized by the Issuer to,
_inter alia, complete the Acquisition as described in the section “Use of Proceeds” without being subject to the_
escrow arrangements described in this Offering Memorandum. In which case, the escrow-related mechanics (but
not the special mandatory redemption provisions) described in this Offering Memorandum shall be deemed
redundant, except as set forth in the following sentence. See “Description of the Notes—Escrow of Proceeds;
_Special Mandatory Redemption.” In the event that, the Acquisition is not consummated within three business_
days following the release of the gross proceeds of the Offering (or the Escrowed Property, as applicable), the
Issuer shall deposit (or redeposit) with the Escrow Agent such amount, which shall thereupon be held by the
Escrow Agent in accordance with the Escrow Agreement and the Escrow Charge and subject to the terms
therein.

Upon release of the proceeds from escrow, the proceeds of the Offering will be used as described in the section
titled “Use of Proceeds.”

The Escrowed Property will be limited to the gross proceeds from the Offering, together with any earnings
thereon and investments thereof, if any, and will not include cash to fund any accrued and unpaid interest on
each series of Notes that may be payable in the event of a special mandatory redemption. In the event that the
special mandatory redemption price payable upon such special mandatory redemption of the Notes exceeds the
amount of the applicable Escrowed Property, Holdco is expected to make an equity contribution to the Issuer to
fund the difference between the applicable special mandatory redemption price and the amount of the Escrowed
Property pursuant to a commitment provided by it.


-----

**Use of Proceeds**

On the Acquisition Closing Date, the gross proceeds of the Offering and the Equity Contribution will be used by
the Issuer to fund the Acquisition and to pay the estimated costs and expenses associated with the Transactions.
See “Use of Proceeds.”

**Additional Amounts ...............................** Any payments made by or on behalf of the Issuer or any
Guarantor (if any) in respect of the Notes or with respect to any
Guarantee will be made without withholding or deduction for
taxes in any relevant taxing jurisdiction unless required by law.
Subject to certain exceptions and limitations, if the Issuer, any
Guarantor (if any) or the paying agent is required by law to
withhold or deduct such taxes with respect to a payment on any
Note, such Issuer or Guarantor (if any) will pay the additional
amounts necessary so that the net amount received by each holder
after such withholding is not less than the amount that would have
been received in the absence of the withholding.

The Issuer is organized under the laws of the Republic of Italy and
therefore payments of principal and interest on the Notes and, in
certain circumstances, any gain on the Notes, will be subject to
Italian tax laws and regulations. Subject to and as set forth in
“Description of the Notes—Withholding Taxes,” the Issuer will


-----

not be liable to pay any additional amounts to holders of the Notes
if any withholding or deduction is required pursuant to Italian
Legislative Decree No. 239 of April 1, 1996 (as the same may be
amended or supplemented from time to time) (“Decree No. 239”)
or pursuant to Italian Legislative Decree No. 461 of November 21,
1997 (as the same may be amended or supplemented from time to
time) (“Decree No. 461”), except, in the case of Decree No. 239
and Decree No. 461, where the procedures required under Decree
No. 239 or Decree No. 461, as applicable, in order to benefit from
an exemption have not been complied with due to solely the
actions or omissions of the Issuer or its agents. See “Description
_of the Notes—Withholding Taxes.”_

Although we believe that, under current law, Italian substitute tax
will not be imposed under Decree No. 239 or Decree No. 461
where a holder of Notes is resident for tax purposes in a country
which allows for a satisfactory exchange of information with Italy
included in the list provided for by Italian Ministerial Decree
dated September 4, 1996, as amended from time to time, or, as
from the tax year in which the Ministerial Decree to be issued
under Article 11, paragraph 4, let. c) of Decree No. 239 is
effective, included in the list therein provided (the “White List”)
and such holder of Notes complies with certain certification
requirements, there is no assurance that this will be the case.
Moreover, holders of the Notes will bear the risk of any change in
Decree No. 239 or Decree No. 461 after the date hereof, including
any change in the White List countries. See “Description of the
_Notes—Withholding Taxes.” Prospective purchasers of Notes_
should consult their tax advisors as to the overall tax
consequences of acquiring, holding and disposing of the Notes
and receiving payments of interest, principal and/or other amounts
under the Notes, including, in particular, the effect of any state,
regional or local tax laws of any country or territory.

**Optional Redemption for Tax Reasons .** If certain changes in the law of any relevant taxing jurisdiction are
announced and become effective on or after the issuance of the
Notes that would require the Issuer or the Guarantors (if any) to
pay additional amounts (as defined in “Description of the Notes—
_Withholding Taxes”), the Issuer may redeem such series of Notes_
in whole, but not in part, at any time, at a redemption price of
100% of the principal amount thereof, plus accrued and unpaid
interest and additional amounts, if any, to but excluding the
redemption date.

**Change of Control ..................................** Upon certain events defined as constituting a change of control,
the Issuer may be required to make an offer to purchase the
outstanding Notes at a purchase price equal to 101% of the
principal amount thereof, plus accrued and unpaid interest and
additional amounts, if any, to the date of purchase. However, a
change of control will not be deemed to have occurred if a
specified consolidated senior secured net leverage ratio is not
exceeded in connection with such event. See “Description of the
_Notes—Change of Control.”_

**Tender Offers ..........................................** In connection with any tender offers for any series of Notes, if
holders of not less than 90% in aggregate principal amount of the
applicable outstanding Notes of such series validly tender and do
not withdraw such Notes in such tender offer and the Issuer, or
any third party making such a tender offer in lieu of the Issuer,
purchases, all of such Notes validly tendered and not withdrawn


-----

by such holders, the Issuer or such third party will have the right
to redeem the Notes of such series that remain outstanding in
whole, but not in part, following such purchase at a price equal to
the price offered to each other holder of the Notes of such series
(excluding any early tender or incentive fee) plus accrued and
unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to, but excluding,
the redemption date. See “Description of the Notes—Optional
_Redemption—General.”_

**Certain Covenants ..................................** The Indenture, among other things, will restrict the ability of the
Issuer and its restricted subsidiaries to:

                    - incur or guarantee additional indebtedness and issue
certain preferred stock;

                    - pay dividends, redeem capital stock and make certain
investments;

                    - make certain other restricted payments;

                    - create or permit to exist certain liens;

                    - impose restrictions on the ability of the Issuer’s
subsidiaries to pay dividends;

                    - transfer or sell certain assets;

                    - merge or consolidate with other entities;

                    - enter into certain transactions with affiliates; and

                    - impair the security interests for the benefit of the holders
of the Notes.

Certain of the covenants will be suspended if the Notes obtain and
maintain an investment-grade rating.

Each of the covenants in the Indenture will be subject to
significant exceptions and qualifications. See “Description of the
_Notes—Certain Covenants.”_

**Transfer Restrictions ..............................** The Notes have not been, and will not be, registered under the
U.S. Securities Act or the securities laws of any other jurisdiction.
The Notes are subject to restrictions on transferability and resale.
See “Transfer Restrictions.” We have not agreed to, or otherwise
undertaken to, register the Notes under the securities laws in any
jurisdiction (including by way of an exchange offer).

**No Established Market ..........................** The Notes will be new securities for which there is currently no
established trading market. Although the Initial Purchasers have
advised us that they intend to make a market in the Notes, they are
not obligated to do so and they may discontinue market making at
any time without notice. Accordingly, there is no assurance that
an active trading market will develop for the Notes.

**Listing ......................................................** Application will be made for the Notes to be listed on the Official
List of the Luxembourg Stock Exchange and admitted to trading
on the Euro MTF Market thereof in accordance with the rules
thereof. There is no assurance that the Notes will be, or will


-----

remain, listed and admitted to trading on the Euro MTF Market.

**Risk Factors ............................................** Investing in the Notes involves substantial risks. You should
consider carefully all the information in this Offering
Memorandum and, in particular, you should evaluate the specific
risk factors set forth in the “Risk Factors” section before making a
decision whether to invest in the Notes.

**Governing Law .......................................** The Indenture and the Notes will be governed by the laws of the
State of New York. The Intercreditor Agreement is, and the
Revolving Credit Facility Agreement, the Escrow Agreement and
the Escrow Charge will be, governed by English law. The security
documents will be governed by the applicable law of the
jurisdiction under which the security interests are granted.

The following tables set out the key economic and financial indicators used by our management to monitor the
group’s performance (“Alternative Performance Measures” or “APMs”) for the periods indicated. These
APMs are not recognized as measures of financial performance or liquidity under Italian GAAP, IFRS or any
other accounting standards. These APMs are used by management as a supplemental measure of performance
and should not be unduly relied on. All non-GAAP Measures are unaudited.

We define EBIT as the sum of profit after tax, income taxes, value adjustments of financial assets, financial
income and expenses, foreign exchange gains and losses, and EBIT margin as the ratio between EBIT and the
value of production. We define EBITDA as the sum of profit for the period, income taxes, effects of investments
using the equity method, financial income and expenses, foreign exchange gains and losses and amortization
and depreciation, and EBITDA Margin as the ratio between EBITDA. We define Adjusted EBIT as EBIT
adjusted for goodwill amortization and non-recurring items, and Adjusted EBIT margin as the ratio between
Adjusted EBIT and the value of production. We define Adjusted EBITDA as EBITDA adjusted for bad debt
accruals and non-recurring items, and Adjusted EBITDA margin as the ratio between Adjusted EBITDA and the
value of production. For further information including definitions of these non-GAAP measures, see
“Presentation of Financial and Other Information—Use of Non-GAAP Financial Measures.”

(i)      The run-rate adjustment for enrolled students has been calculated by (i) restating the revenue related to tuition fees of newly
enrolled undergraduate students for each academic year (approximately €4 million adjustment) and (ii) annualizing the
revenues related to tuition fees for the 2023/2024 academic year of new undergraduate students enrolled between August 1,
2023 and December 31, 2023 (approximately €35 million adjustment), each as further described below.

Revenues are currently recognized in line with accounting principles but for the purposes of this adjustment have been restated
to be spread evenly between the twelve months of an academic year (running from August 1 of a given year to July 31 of the
following year). Under accounting principles, the Group recognizes revenue from tuition fees of newly enrolled students from
the enrolment date until the end of the relevant academic year, spread evenly. For new undergraduate students enrolled
between August 1 and December 31, revenues are partially recognized in the financial year in which the enrollment date occurs
and partially deferred to the next financial year. For new undergraduate students enrolled between January 1 and July 31,
revenues are fully recognized in the financial year in which the enrollment date occurs, with no revenues accrued in the
previous financial year. The revenue restatement for enrolled students has been calculated by restating the revenue related to
tuition fees of newly enrolled undergraduate students for each academic year by recognizing 5/12 of such revenues in the
financial year in which the academic year starts (i.e., to cover the period from August 1 to December 31 of such academic year)
and 7/12 in the financial year in which the academic year ends (to cover the period from January 1 until July 31 of such
academic year) irrespective of the enrollment date during the relevant academic year.

The annualization of revenues (including certain estimates) related to tuition fees for the 2023/2024 academic year of new
undergraduate students enrolled between August 1, 2023 and December 31, 2023 represents the estimated run-rate effect from


-----

an increase in undergraduate student enrollments and an increase in undergraduate tuition fees for the 2023/2024 academic
year compared to the prior academic year, as adjusted by applying the Group’s historical churn rate (5% for the year ended
December 31, 2023) and gross margin (81% for the year ended December 31, 2023). The Group’s historical churn rate reflects
the impact of student withdrawals, deferred or on-hold students, transferred students and blocked (non-paying) students. The
Group also removed the revenue relating to tuition fees for the 2022/2023 academic year of undergraduate students who
graduated during the period.

The run-rate adjustment for enrolled students is derived from management estimates, is not part of our Consolidated Financial
Statements or our accounting records and has not been audited or otherwise reviewed by our auditors. The run-rate adjustment
for enrolled students is presented for information purposes only and does not purport to represent the actual contribution of the
increase in undergraduate student enrollments or tuition fees to our results of operations and financial condition for the period
presented nor does it purport to present such contribution for any future period. The Group’s estimated run-rate adjustment for
enrolled students is based on a number of estimates and assumptions made in reliance on the information available at the time
made and judgments based on such information, including the number of students expected to enrol between the date of
calculation and July 31. The assumptions used in such estimates are inherently uncertain, subject to change and could cause the
Group’s actual results to differ materially from those contained in such estimates. The Group calculated such figures based on

be up-to-date or may not be prepared on the same basis on which the Group prepares its audited accounts. Such information
