**Overview**

**_General_**

Established in 2006, Multiversity is the leading university in the Italian online higher education market with
approximately 151,000 undergraduate enrolled students (and approximately 206,000 enrolled students in total)
for the 2022/2023 academic year. Based on the number of university students enrolled for the 2022/2023
academic year, the company has an estimated market share in the Italian online academic education of 57%, an
estimated market share in the Italian academic education (across both physical and online universities) of 8%[43]
and a student satisfaction rate of 98%[44]. Multiversity also has a leading role in the foundation of UNITED (the
first association of Italian online universities). It operates several education assets, and in particular:

  - Online universities: Multiversity operates three fully licensed private online universities in Italy with
MIUR accreditations: Università Telematica Pegaso S.r.l. (“Pegaso”), Universitas Mercatorum
(“Mercatorum”) and Università Telematica San Raffaele Roma S.r.l. (“San Raffaele”). It provides a
student centric proposition with a wide array of undergraduate and post graduate courses to
approximately 206,000 students for the 2022/2023 academic year and is supported by a strong
professor base (10 Multiversity professors have been included in the “Top Scientists – World Top 2%”
ranking from Stanford University). Degrees awarded at the end of academic courses have the same
legal value as degrees issued by traditional universities. 97.4% of Multiversity’s revenue for the year
ended December 31, 2023 was generated by the university segment.

  - Non-academic courses and certifications: Multiversity has also expanded into a complementary nonuniversity education segment, mainly focusing on: (i) B2B and B2C executive education through Sole
24 Ore Formazione S.p.A. (“Sole 24 Ore Formazione”), (ii) digital skills through Aulab S.r.l.
(“Aulab”), a coding factory, which delivers short term courses for software developers, and (iii) a

44 Global Management Company, Market Report.

certification entity, Certipass S.r.l. (“Certipass”). 2.3% of Multiversity’s revenue for the year ended
December 31, 2023 was generated by the non-academic education segment.

  - Other assets: Multiversity also operates a number of academies offering courses on specific subjects
(e.g. communication, marketing and law) as well as other assets (e.g. Principe di Napoli, which
provides gastronomy and tourism higher education, or Benecon, a research center promoted by the
Campania Region). 0.3% of Multiversity’s revenues for the year ended December 31, 2023 were
generated by the other assets segment.

Multiversity delivers its services through a proprietary online platform that produces its e-learning content,
which is developed in-house. In addition, Multiversity is also a pioneer in the use of artificial intelligence in
education, in particular for marketing purposes and for the development of new use cases (such as its Tutor
Chatbot and Exam Generator applications).

**_Online universities_**

Pegaso is Multiversity’s largest university. Approximately 140,000 students were enrolled in Pegaso’s online
courses for the 2022/2023 academic year. Pegaso offers a range of both undergraduate and postgraduate courses,
and in particular eight undergraduate bachelor’s degrees, five specialist master’s degrees, one single cycle fiveyear degree and 158 courses, including postgraduate master’s courses and higher education and specialization
courses for professionals and high school graduates. Pegaso also offers individual certifications and gives
students the possibility to undertake single examinations for each course module upon payment of a fee without
having to complete the full course.

Multiversity’s second key institution, Mercatorum, is 66.67% owned by Multiversity, with the remaining
33.33% stake held by Unioncamere, the Italian Union of Chambers of Commerce, Industry, Crafts and
Agriculture, which is the public body that unifies and institutionally represents the Italian system of chambers of
commerce. Approximately 53,000 students were enrolled in Mercatorum for the 2022/2023 academic year.
Mercatorum’s core offering consists of 14 undergraduate bachelor’s degrees, five specialist master’s degrees,
five Ph.D. programs and 121 courses, including postgraduate master’s courses and higher education and
specialization courses for professionals and high school graduates.

Multiversity’s third primary institution in terms of revenue, San Raffaele, became part of the Group in 2022, and
it is wholly owned by Multiversity. San Raffaele delivers courses mainly related to biomedical and healthcare
sciences, and it ranks first in research quality among digital universities and fifth among the entire national
university system.[45] Approximately 13,000 students were enrolled in San Raffaele for the 2022/2023 academic
year, and its core offering currently consists of four undergraduate bachelor’s degrees, three specialist master’s
degrees, six Ph.D. programs and 39 postgraduate master’s courses.

**_Non-academic courses and certifications_**

In relation to the non-university education segment, Multiversity operates Sole 24 Ore Formazione in
partnership with Il Sole 24 Ore S.p.A. (with Multiversity holding a majority stake of 85%) to deliver B2B and
B2C executive master's courses to professionals and young graduates. As part of the B2B offerings, Multiversity
also offers compulsory courses, soft skills, industry and managerial training to corporates. These courses can be
offered as off-the shelf, co-designed or fully customized. The B2B courses can vary in length, while the B2C
courses typically last one to six months. The new partnership benefits from a top level academic and scientific
training offer, thanks to the support of the universities that are part of the Group as well as the support and the
strong brand recognition of the Il Sole 24 Ore group (owning the 15% of Sole 24 Ore Formazione), one of the
leading finance newspapers in Italy, which provides content to readers, professionals, businesses, and
institutions on topics of economics, finance, and management. Additionally, Multiversity owns 60.61% of
Aulab, a player in the digital training sector for developers with a high placement rate of its students thanks to
an effective training model for coding and IT education, an efficient placement platform and partnerships with
top companies. This training model requires no pre-requisites and typically lasts from three to 6 months. In
addition to training, Aulab also designs and develops websites, IT platforms and software applications. The nonuniversity segment also includes Certipass, a provider of international EIPASS certifications for digital
competences and IT skills.

**_Academies and other assets_**

The Group also includes a number of academies established through collaboration agreements between Pegaso,
Mercatorum and San Raffaele and their respective commercial partners, covering a wide range of specialist
subjects such as marketing, communications and media and teaching. Other assets include Principe di Napoli
S.a.r.l. (“Principe di Napoli”), established in February 2019 by Pegaso in partnership with Mercatorum
(holding 90% and 10% stakes, respectively) as a center for higher education and specialization in the sectors of
gastronomy and tourism. Apart from the Postgraduate School in Legal Professions (as further described below),
Principe di Napoli is one of the few institution within Multiversity to hold on premise courses. Additionally, in
December 2023, the Group acquired a minority stake in Materias S.r.l., an incubator of scientific research
activities engaged in identifying innovative ideas in the field of advanced materials, primarily generated from
the academic sector.

Multiversity also operates a publishing entity and companies dedicated to research, which are mostly ancillary
and in support of the three universities. Almost the entirety of its operations are located in Italy, with some
limited operations in Malta (Pegaso International). It also has collaboration agreements with several partners in
Italy for the development and delivery of specialized courses in a multitude of subjects, made available through
its three universities.

In order to support their online offering, Multiversity’s institutions have an extensive network of approximately
1,000[46] e-learning center points (the “ELCPs”) as of December 31, 2023. The ELCPs provide information to
prospective and current students about the various institutions and serve as orientation centers for new students
throughout the entire duration of the course they undertake. The ELCP Points performed orientation activities
for approximately 61% of Multiversity’s institution’s new students as of December 31, 2023; however, the
relevant institution retains the direct relationship with student as it manages the enrollment process and tuition
fee payments directly with the student[47]. As regards the ELCP Points across Certipass, these purchase EIPASS
cards from Certipass and on-sell them to customers who wish to obtain an EIPASS certification. All ELCPs are
managed by external third parties that have entered into specific accreditation agreements with Pegaso,
Mercatorum, San Raffaele or Certipass (in some cases, more than one institution has entered into an
accreditation agreement with the same ELCP). See “Material Contracts—Accreditation agreements for ELCPs”
below.

**_Financial Performance_**

Multiversity’s revenues for the financial year ended December 31, 2023 amounted to €419.9 million, as
compared to €332.0 million for the prior financial year ended December 31, 2022 (an increase of 26.5%).
Enrolled undergraduate students at Pegaso, Mercatorum and San Raffaele increased by approximately 28% in
the 2022/2023 academic year with respect to the 2021/2022 academic year.

In addition, Adjusted EBITDA generated for the year ended December 31, 2023 was €247.2 million as
compared to €200.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2022 (an increase of 23.6%). Adjusted EBITDA
margin for the year ended December 31, 2023 was 58.9%, as compared to 60.2% for the year ended December
31, 2022.

Furthermore, Adjusted Operating Free Cash Flow generated for the year ended December 31, 2023 was €226.0
million, as compared to €157.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2022 (an increase of 43%). Adjusted
Cash Conversion for the year ended December 31, 2023 was 91%, as compared to 79% for the year ended
December 31, 2022 (an increase of 12%).

**_Business Model_**

Multiversity’s business model is based on a student-centric offering of a flexible learning experience and access
to teaching content through its proprietary and technologically advanced e-learning platform. Multiversity’s
universities address specific unmet demand in the market for a flexible path to an undergraduate degree, whilst
catering to specific professions for postgraduate continuous learning.

46 Some entities perform services for, and have entered into accreditation agreements with, more than one of Pegaso,
Mercatorum, San Raffaele and Certipass.

47 With reference to the 2022/2023 academic year.


-----

Revenues are mainly driven by tuition fees paid by students, which contributed to 75%[48] of Multiversity’s
revenues. Almost the entirety of tuition fees is self-funded by students, with less than 1% paid through
scholarships. The levels of tuition fees in turn depend on the number of students, the nature or class of degree
undertaken, the year of enrollment, the type of course and the student’s selected enrollment channel, amongst
other factors. Undergraduate degrees, which are multi-year courses (three-year bachelor’s degree plus a twoyear specialist master’s degree, or a single-cycle five-year degree), are a recurring multi-year revenue stream for
the term of the program (consisting of both the tuition fees and any other ancillary fees), which has an average
course length of approximately 2.4 years. Approximately 30% of Multiversity's graduates who have completed
three-year undergraduate degree courses wish to continue their education and apply to enroll in two-year
specialist master’s degree and master’s degree courses with the same institution.

On the other hand, one-year postgraduate courses (i.e. second level master’s which may be undertaken by
students who have already completed a three year undergraduate bachelor’s degree plus a two year specialist
master’s degree or a single-cycle five year degree), together with higher education courses and specialization
courses, provide a one-off tuition fee payment per student, accounting for 6% of Multiversity’s revenues for the
financial year ended December 31, 2023. Various other services offered to students provide additional revenue
such as fees payable in order to take examinations in an alternative location, and certificates; such additional
services accounted for approximately 14% of Multiversity’s revenues for the financial year ended December 31,
2023. Single exams contributed to 1% of Multiversity’s revenues for the year ended December 31, 2023. The
non-academic business segment (including Certipass, Aulab and Sole 24 Ore Formazione) accounted for
approximately 2% of Multiversity revenues for the year ended December 31, 2023.

The other assets segment (which include Principe di Napoli, Benecon and other smaller companies) accounted
for 0.3% of Multiversity’s revenues for the year ended December 31, 2023.

With respect to student orientation, around 61% of new students as of December 31, 2023 (contributing to 62%
of commercial revenues for the 2022/2023 academic year) across Pegaso, Mercatorum and San Raffaele partook
in orientation activities at the approximately 1,000 ELCPs that make up Multiversity’s national network.
Approximately 39% of students as of December 31, 2023 (contributing to 38% of commercial revenues for the
2022/2023 academic year) were reached through traditional marketing methods, e.g. billboards and TV
advertising campaigns on both private and public Italian channels, as well as through its extensive online
presence on social media and online advertising, thereby gaining access to the widest possible audience and
delivery tangible results, with an increase in new leads of 50% in 2023 compared to 2022. Multiversity has
established a nation-wide presence, with approximately 100 exam venues located in prestigious and historical
buildings, along with a strong online social community and proprietary technology platforms for online classes,
exams and tutoring.

Multiversity’s growth strategy is predominantly based on expanding volumes by increasing market penetration
within the population, whilst selectively increasing its course offering, its brand awareness, digital marketing
practices and _ad hoc_ orientation services to prospective students as well as by entering into commercial
agreements and partnerships.

Additionally, revenues are driven by increases in our tuition fees taking into account inflation and other
commercial considerations. For example, Multiversity increased its undergraduate tuition fees for newly
enrolling students by approximately 8% on average for the 2022/2023 academic year, as compared to the prior
academic year. See further “Business—Competitive Strengths” and “Business—Business Strategy.”

The main objective underpinning Multiversity’s business strategy is to consolidate its market position and
strengthen its position as the leading entirely online education group in the Italian market, employing both
Business-to-Consumer and Business-to-Business marketing strategies in order to target an ever-wider audience
of students. See further “Business—Competitive Strengths” and “Business—Business Strategy.”

**_Macroeconomic Conditions and Demand_**

Nearly all of our revenues were derived from our operations in Italy. In the year ended December 31, 2023, our
operations in Italy represented more than 99% of our revenue, with the remainder being generated in Malta. As
a result, our results of operations are, and will continue to be affected by, macroeconomic and political
developments in or affecting Italy and, in particular, the impact of such developments on the demand for private
university and post-graduate education. Demand is driven by factors including GDP, consumer confidence and
disposable income levels, interest rates, inflation, changes to Italy’s sovereign credit rating and liquidity
concerns in financial markets, which can impact enrolment figures and our ability to raise the fees we charge.
For further information, see “Risk Factors—Adverse changes in certain macroeconomic factors may negatively
_affect Multiversity's business, results of operations, financial condition and prospects.”_

Mercatorum and San Raffaele.

In the 2022/2023 academic year, according to MIUR, approximately 1.9 million undergraduate students enrolled
at Italian universities, which represents an increase of approximately 40,000 (or 2%) compared to the previous
academic year and an increase of approximately 200,000 (or 11%) compared to the level recorded over the last
decade. The increase in new enrollments at Italian universities is primarily driven by a growth in enrollments at
online universities, which is in turn mainly driven by flexibility of degree programmes, greater availability of
exam sessions available and cost savings (Market Report).

**_Tuition Fees_**

Our primary source of revenue is tuition fees, representing 75% of our revenues for the year ended December
31, 2023. Revenues from tuition fees amounted to €316.7 million, €244.2 million and €190.3 million in the

considerations. We set our tuition fees at the start of the academic year for newly enrolling students. For

In the 2022/2023 academic year, new undergraduate enrollments increased by approximately 33% and our
tuition fees for newly enrolling students increased by approximately 8% on average, from approximately €1,600
per year in the 2021/2022 academic year to approximately €1,700 per year in the 2022/2023 academic year. This

**_Acquisitions and Partnerships_**

We have historically expanded our operations through acquisitions of other universities as well as non-academic
institutions. Through our strategic acquisitions and partnerships, we have been able to offer to students a more
expansive and comprehensive range of education products and services.

Our significant acquisitions since January 1, 2021 include:

  - On September 16, 2022, the acquisition of 60.61% of Aulab, a company active in the training of
software developers, which also designs and develops websites, IT platforms and software applications.
This acquisition is reflected in our results of operations from September 30, 2022.

  - On October 4, 2022, the acquisition of the entire share capital of San Raffaele, an academic institution
that delivers courses mainly related to biomedical and healthcare sciences. This acquisition is reflected
in our results of operations from October 31, 2022.

  - On October 3, 2022, the entry into an investment and shareholders’ agreement with Il Sole 24 Ore
S.p.A., one of the leading Italian finance newspapers (holding a minority stake of 15%, while we hold
the remaining 85%) to establish a partnership to operate Sole 24 Ore Formazione, which delivers B2B
and B2C executive master's courses to professionals and young graduates. This partnership is reflected
in our results of operations from November 9, 2022.

Acquisitions and partnerships impact our financial position and results of operations in a variety of ways. For
example, we incur costs related to the acquisition of the business, including the purchase price of the acquired
business and the costs of integrating it. In addition, acquisitions and partnerships can impact the comparability
of our results between periods as our results for the period during which an acquisition takes place include the
results of the acquired business only from the date of completion of the acquisition and the full impact of the
acquired business is only reflected in subsequent periods. See “—Key Factors Affecting Comparability—
_Acquisitions” below._

**_Interest rate fluctuations_**

Our financial expenses are affected by the movement of interest rates, particularly EURIBOR, which is the
reference rate for most of our floating rate borrowings, including the Existing Notes and the Existing Revolving
Credit Facility. Almost 100% of our borrowings are subject to a floating interest rate. Our policy is to hedge a
portion of our interest rate risk by entering into interest rate swaps, which seek to convert a portion of our
floating rate liabilities into fixed rate liabilities. However, we are not fully hedged and we remain exposed to
changes in interest rates on our unhedged borrowings and on the fair value of our interest rate swaps. As of the
date of this Offering Memorandum, approximately 65% of the outstanding principal amount of our floating rate
borrowings was hedged through a derivative financial instrument (caps with 0.5% strike) expiring in April 2025,
with €265 million in notional amount of interest rate swaps. See also “—Quantitative and Qualitative
_Disclosures about Market Risk—Interest rate risk.”_

In the year ended December 31, 2023, we experienced an increase in financial expenses due to the rise in
EURIBOR over the period, which resulted in increased interest payments on our floating rate borrowings to the
extent unhedged. We monitor the interest rate environment and the effectiveness of our hedging strategy on a


-----

regular basis and may adjust our hedging position as appropriate to achieve our desired risk profile. We also
consider the availability and cost of alternative sources of financing and the maturity profile of our debt
portfolio to optimize our capital structure and liquidity position.

**_Key Performance Indicators_**

The demographic profile of our students is a key operational metric to manage our educational institutions. We
monitor the age, year of enrollment, origin and geography of our students as we believe that they are the most
reliable metrics for measuring the profitability of our educational institutions.

Undergraduates make up the majority of our student population and we tend to observe a high incidence of (i)
younger students (students aged 18-34) and first-generation students (i.e., students accessing higher education
for the first time) which have been and are expected to increase in the near future; and (ii) students from
Southern Italy and Islands (as a reflection of our original footprint).

For further information, see “Business—Demographics of Multiversity’s Student Population.”

**Key Factors Affecting Comparability**

**_Acquisitions_**

We account for acquisitions in subsidiaries using the acquisition method of accounting and the book value of the
investments consolidated on a line-by-line basis is eliminated against the corresponding portion of shareholders’
equity, less the result for the year, at the date of first inclusion in the consolidation. The difference between the
acquisition cost and the net equity of the subsidiaries at the date of first consolidation is allocated, where
possible, to the assets and liabilities of the subsidiaries net of the related deferred taxes, where applicable; any
remaining difference, if positive and if the requirements for recording goodwill provided for by OIC 24 are met,
is recognized in the item ‘Goodwill’ within intangible assets.

For a list of our material acquisitions since January 1, 2021 and the date from which the acquired companies
have been consolidated into the Consolidated Financial Statements, see “—Acquisitions and Partnerships.”

**_2021 Acquisition and 2022 Reverse Merger_**

As a result of the 2021 Acquisition and the 2022 Reverse Merger described further under “Presentation of
_Financial and Other Information—2021 Acquisition and 2022 Reverse Merger”, the financial information of_
the Group as of and for the years ended December 31, 2023 and 2022 reflects the results of operation and
financial condition of Multiversity S.p.A. (the surviving entity) and its consolidated subsidiaries (including the
results of operations and financial condition of the Perimeter Assets). The financial information as of and for the
year ended December 31, 2021 presented herein reflects the results of operations and financial condition of
Multiversity S.r.l. (which was converted into Multiversity S.p.A. following the 2022 Reverse Merger) and its
consolidated subsidiaries only and does not completely reflect the results of operations and financial condition
of the Perimeter Assets. As a result, the financial information presented as of and for the year ended December
31, 2021 is not directly comparable to the financial information presented for subsequent periods. For additional
information, see “Presentation of Financial and Other Information.” From an accounting perspective, the
comparability of financial information presented as of and for the years ended December 31, 2021 and 2022
result from the purchase price accounting and debt financing in connection with the 2021 Acquisition and the
subsequent effects of the 2022 Reverse Merger, each as described in more detail in notes 6.2 and 6.4 of the
2023/2022 Consolidated Financial Statements. While the 2021 Acquisition affects comparability of the balance
sheet, amortization and finance costs across the two periods, it does not materially affect comparability of our
underlying business performance as presented in our revenues, production value, production costs (other than
increased depreciation and amortization as a result of purchase price accounting) or EBITDA.

**Description of Key Line Items and Certain Key Performance Indicators of Multiversity**

**_Value of production_**

The value of production primarily comprises the operating income from the educational offerings of Pegaso,
Mercatorum and San Raffaele, as well as from Certipass and Aulab, all included in the consolidated financial
statements using the line-by-line method (which involves the inclusion of all assets, liabilities, income and


-----

expenses in their entirety, irrespective of the size of the holding, and the attribution to minority shareholders,
under the items “capital and reserves pertaining to minority interests” and “profit (loss) of minority interests”
respectively). These include fees for enrollment in degree, postgraduate and single courses, contributions from
students, off-site exams, issuing diplomas and certificates, and training courses.

Revenue from sales and services are recognized on the basis of the relevant accounting principles and are shown
as net of returns, discounts, rebates and premiums.

Other revenues and income mainly concern grants related to university research projects and to ancillary
services relating to the educational offerings of Pegaso, Mercatorum and San Raffaele.

Most of our revenues from newly enrolled academic students are deferred on the basis of the academic year
which starts on August 1 and ends on July 31 of the following year, calculating the actual days. See “Critical
_Accounting Policies—Receivables.” The tuition fees for undergraduate courses and academic master’s degrees_
are due in four equal installments payable in November, May, June and July of each academic year, while the
tuition fees for postgraduate master’s courses and single courses are paid as a lump sum.

**_Costs of production_**

Operating costs comprise the direct and indirect costs attributable to our operations and mainly include the costs
of services, costs for use of third-party assets, personnel costs, other operating expenses and amortization,
depreciation and write-downs.

_Costs of services_

The largest components of costs of services are advertising and contributions to guidance centers. Costs of
services also include teaching, the corporate bodies compensation, technical and financial advisory fees,
insurance, bank and postal charges, utilities, maintenance and other costs, and contribution to ELCPs.

_Costs for use of third-party assets_

The cost for use of third-party assets primarily relates to rental costs for the offices of the universities of the
Group, rental of cars and other equipment used in the operating activities of the Group, and royalties for use of
the Multiversity name and platform.

_Cost of personnel_

The cost of personnel reflects all expenses for employees including wages and salaries, social security charges,
the cost of unused holidays, legal provisions and collective agreements.

_Other operating expenses_

Other operating expenses mainly include costs for stamp duty, donations to organizations and associations,
various taxes and duties and contingent liabilities.

_Amortization, depreciation and write-downs_

The most significant component of amortization, depreciation and write-downs is the amortization of intangible
assets. This is mainly comprised of the amortization of goodwill and also contains the amortization of
trademarks, platforms and other rights. Amortization, depreciation and write-downs also includes write-downs
for bad debt, provisions, and depreciation of plant, property and equipment.

Depreciation and amortization are determined on a straight-line basis to the historical cost, including directly
attributable accessory charges, of property, plant and equipment and intangible assets, respectively, with
goodwill being depreciated over 20 years. Write-downs for impairment of property, plant and equipment and
intangible assets is recognized when their recoverable value is lower than their book value. Write-downs of
trade receivables are recognized to align their carrying amount to their presumed realisable value and in
connection with losses incurred.


-----

_Financial income and expenses_

Financial income and expenses include all the positive and negative components, respectively, of the results for
the year connected with the financial activity of the Group and are recognized on the basis of the accrual
principle. Financial income is largely comprised of the discounting of receivables and financial expenses is
primarily comprised of interest expense on bond and other financial payables.

**_Income taxes_**

Current income taxes are allocated according to the accrual principle on the basis of the income tax charges
resulting from the application of tax legislation in force and are reflected based on tax payables net of advances.

Deferred and prepaid taxes are determined based on the temporary differences between the value attributed to
the tax assets and liabilities according to statutory criteria and the value attributed to the same assets and
liabilities for current tax purposes.

Deferred tax liabilities are entered in the ‘Provision for deferred taxes’, recorded under liabilities among the
provisions for risks and charges, while the deferred tax assets are recorded within the receivables from others
under current assets.

Deferred tax assets are not recognized, in compliance with the prudence principle, if there is not reasonable
certainty of the existence, in the fiscal years in which the relative temporary differences will be reversed, of a
taxable income higher than the amount of the differences that will be cancelled. Liabilities for deferred taxes are
recognized only if there is a reasonable certainty that they will reverse in the foreseeable future. Deferred tax
assets and deferred tax liabilities are valued at the estimated tax rates applicable in the year in which the tax
asset will be realised or the tax liability will be settled, based on the tax legislation established by the provisions
in force at the reporting date.

_Revenues from sales and services_

The revenues from sales and services of the Group increased by €85.8 million, or 26.1%, from €328.7 million
for the year ended December 31, 2022 to €414.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2023. The increase
was primarily due to higher student enrollments in both undergraduate and post-graduate courses, an increase in
tuition fees for new enrollments, non-tuition fee increases due to higher enrollment in undergraduate courses,
and the impact of the acquisition of San Raffaele, Sole 24 Ore Formazione and Aulab, which were fully
consolidated for the year ended December 31, 2023 in comparison to the three months revenue contributions of
Aulab and the two months revenue contributions of San Raffaele and Sole 24 Ore Formazione for the year
ended December 31, 2022.

Excluding the revenue contributions generated by the acquisition of San Raffaele, equal to €5.2 million for the
year ended December 31, 2022 (limited to the two months consolidation) and to €30.2 for the year ended
December 31, 2023, the revenues from sales and services of the Group increased by €60.8 million, or 18.8%,
from €323.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2022 to €384.3 million for the year ended December 31,
2023.

Pegaso is the largest single contributor to Multiversity’s results and accounted for 65.9% of Multiversity’s
revenues from sales and services for the financial year ended December 31, 2023. Mercatorum accounted for
24.3% of Multiversity’s revenues from sales and services for the financial year ended December 31, 2023. San
Raffaele accounted for 7.3% of Multiversity’s revenues from sales and services for the financial year ended
December 31, 2023.

_Other revenues and income_

Value of production includes other revenues and income of the Group, which increased by €1.9 million, or
55.9%, from €3.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2022 to €5.3 million for the year ended December
31, 2023 and were primarily associated with grants for research projects of Pegaso, Mercatorum and San
Raffaele.

**_Costs of production_**

_Costs for services_

Costs for services of the Group increased by €25.0 million, or 26.7%, from €93.4 million for the year ended
December 31, 2022 to €118.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2023, primarily due to increases in
contributions relating to ELCPs, costs incurred for promotional activities, teachers’ salaries and technical, legal
and administrative consultancy costs. However, costs for services did not register a significant change as a
percentage of the total value of production across the years ended December 31, 2023 and December 31, 2022,
increasing slightly from around 28.1% to 28.2%.

_Costs for use of third party assets_

Costs for use of third party assets of the Group increase by €3.7 million, or 80.0%, from €4.5 million for the
year ended December 31, 2022 to €8.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2023, primarily due to costs
associated with the companies acquired in the year ended December 31, 2022, such as the headquarters of Sole
24 Ore Formazione, the offices of San Raffaele and costs in relation to Aulab, and rental fees for classrooms,
conference centres for exams and graduation ceremonies.

_Cost of personnel_

Personnel costs of the Group increased by €14.9 million, or 53.8%, from €27.7 million for the year ended
December 31, 2022 to €42.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2023. The increase was primarily driven
by a change in the consolidation perimeter due to the acquisition and integration of Aulab, San Raffaele and
Sole 24 Ore Formazione on September 16, 2022, October 4, 2022 and November 9, 2022, respectively, and a
management and staff expansion in Multiversity, Pegaso and Mercatorum in order to support the Group’s past
and expected growth.

_Other operating expenses_

Other operating expenses of the Group increased by €5.9 million, from €13.2 million for the year ended
December 31, 2022 to €19.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2023. This increase was primarily
attributable to the disposal of certain software no longer used by Multiversity.

Our Net Working Capital trend is mainly driven by trade receivables and deferred revenues, with peaks at the
end of the year due to the tuition fees accounting policy applied by the Group. In particular, when a student
enrolls, the Group books accounts receivables for the total amount to be collected against deferred revenues
(reflecting the total amount of tuition fees remaining for the academic year), which is then released on a monthly
basis to profits and losses. Consequently, Net Working Capital is exposed to business seasonality with peaks in
September, due to current students' enrollment renewal occurring at the beginning of the academic year, and in
the fourth quarter, due to the peak of deferred revenues mirroring new students’ enrollment concentration in the
months of October and November, along with the collection of current students’ first installment of tuition fees
in November. See “—Critical Accounting Policies—Receivables.” In the year ended December 31, 2023,
Multiversity changed the payment conditions applied to ELCPs, reducing them from 90 to 30 days, and allowed
tuition to now be paid in eight installments rather than quarterly, both of which are expected to lead to a more
linear trend in Net Working Capital going forward.

**Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures about Market Risk**

The Group activities expose it to a variety of financial risks including credit risk and liquidity risk. The risk
management policy, which is managed centrally by the senior management, focuses on minimizing the potential
adverse effects on our financial performance. The following section discusses the significant financial risks to
which the Group is exposed. This discussion does not address any other risks to which it is exposed to in the
normal course of business such as operational risks. See “Risk Factors.”

**_Interest rate risk_**

The Group will be subject to interest rate market risk in connection with its long-term debt. The Group’s
principal interest rate exposure will relate to variable rate borrowings under the Existing Notes and the Floating
Rate Notes. To the extent that EURIBOR is in excess of the 0.00% floor rate, each one basis point change in
interest rates would result in an approximately €     change in annual interest expense on the funded
indebtedness under the Floating Rate Notes, assuming the Revolving Credit Facility remains undrawn.

**_Credit risk_**

Following the credit monitoring activity carried out on a timely basis by the administrative offices of the group
companies, overdue credit collection activities are constantly implemented, including by strengthening the
administrative staff. The value of the receivables is constantly monitored during the year, and if needed a
provision for the estimated uncollectable receivable is accrued so that the amount expresses the presumed
realisable value.

**_Liquidity Risk and Risk of Changes in Cash Flows_**

Our management body constantly monitors the trends in cash flows through an adequate financial planning
system and any extraordinary funding, also in the context of extraordinary operations, is made after a deep and
prudent liquidity risk analysis. After the Transactions are executed, a certain portion of our cash flows will be
absorbed by the repayment of principles and interests of the borrowings entered into in connection with the 2021
Acquisition.

**_Tax risk_**

All Group companies monitor their tax position on an ongoing basis and implement risk management associated
with prudent tax policies, and with the help of external consultants. On January 12, 2024, a tax audit was
commenced by the Italian Tax Police (Guardia di Finanza) against Pegaso (see “Business—Litigation and legal,
_tax and administrative proceedings”)._

**Critical Accounting Policies**

The financial statements included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum contain a description of certain
significant accounting policies of Multiversity S.p.A. which require the Group to make estimates and
assumptions that affect reported results and disclosures. The Group believes the following items are critical
accounting policies. “Critical accounting policies” means policies that are both important to the portrayal of the
Group’s financial performance and financial results, and that require critical management judgments and
estimates in relation to matters that are inherently uncertain. The estimates and assumptions are based on
experience and various other factors that are believed to be reasonable under the circumstances and are used to
judge the carrying values of assets and liabilities that are not readily apparent from other sources. The estimates
and underlying assumptions are reviewed on an ongoing basis. The most critical accounting policies involving a
higher degree of judgment and complexity in applying principles of valuation and for which changes in the
assumptions and estimates could result in significantly different results than those recorded in the financial
statements included elsewhere in the Offering Memorandum. Although we believe that our discretionary
judgments and estimates are appropriate, actual future results may differ from our estimates.

**_Write-downs for impairment of tangible and intangible assets_**

At each balance sheet date, the Group assesses whether there is any indicator to suggest a fixed asset may have
suffered impairment. If these indicators were to exist, the Group would estimate the recoverable value of the


-----

asset by making a write-down only if the latter were lower than the corresponding net book value. In the
absence of indicators of potential impairment, the recoverable value is not determined.

When it is not possible to estimate the recoverable value of an individual asset, the Group estimates the
recoverable value of the cash-generating unit to which the asset belongs.

The recoverable value of an asset is the greater of the fair value less costs to sell and its value in use determined
as the present value of estimated future cash flows.

An impairment is recognized if the recoverable value is lower than the book value. When, subsequently, a loss
on assets, other than goodwill, ceases or is reduced, the book value of the asset or the cash-generating unit is
increased up to the new estimate of the recoverable value without exceeding the value that would have been
determined if no loss had been detected.

**_Receivables_**

Receivables originating from revenues for the sale of goods or the provision of services are recognized under
current assets on an accrual basis when the conditions for the recognition of the related revenues are met.

The revenue recognition policy is set out below.

Most of the revenues are deferred on the basis of the academic year which starts on August 1 and ends on July
31 of the following year, calculating the actual days.

Revenues deriving from “OLD” undergraduate students (students already enrolled in the previous year) are
accounted for at the beginning of the new academic year (August 1) and deferred through the entire period (until
July 31).

Revenues deriving from “NEW” undergraduate students (new students enrolled) are spread evenly between the
enrollment date and the end of the relevant academic year. For new undergraduate students enrolled between
August and December, revenues are recognized starting from the enrollment date and deferred in equal monthly
installments for the remainder of the academic year. For example, if a student enrolls in August (the beginning
of the academic year), revenue accrues monthly in 12 equal installments for the remainder of the academic year,
with 5/12 of the tuition fee (representing five months) recognized in the year of enrolment and 7/12 of the
tuition fee (representing seven months) recognized in the next financial year. If a student enrolls in October,
revenue accrues monthly in 10 equal installments for the duration of the academic year, with 3/10 of the tuition
fee (representing three months) recognized in the year of enrolment and 7/10 of the tuition fee (representing
seven months) recognized in the next financial year. For new undergraduate students enrolled between January
and July, revenues are fully recognized in the related financial year, with no revenues accrued in the previous
financial year.

FIT revenues are not deferred on the basis of the academic years but according to the following percentages:
50% / 25% / 25% respectively in the accounting month and in the following 2 months. Starting from October
2022, FIT revenues are no longer considered to be a revenue stream due to a change in regulation.

The other types of revenue are directly accounted for in the billing month and therefore are not deferred (as for
EIPASS revenues).

Receivables originating for different reasons are recognized if there is a ‘title’ to the receivable and therefore
when they actually represent a third-party obligation to the company; if of a financial nature they are classified
under financial fixed assets, with an indication of the portion due within the next fiscal year.

Receivables are valued in the financial statements at amortized cost, taking into account the time factor, and
within the limits of their presumed realisable value and, therefore, are shown in the balance sheet net of the
related bad debt provision deemed adequate to cover losses due to reasonably foreseeable non-collectability.

If the interest rate of the transaction is not significantly different from the market rate, the receivable is initially
recorded at a value equal to the nominal value net of all premiums, discounts, rebates and inclusive of any costs
directly attributable to the transaction, which generated the receivable. These transaction costs, any commission


-----

income and expense and any difference between the initial value and the nominal value at maturity are spread
over the duration of the loan using the effective interest criterion.

On the other hand, when the interest rate of the transaction inferable from the contractual conditions is
significantly different from the market rate, the receivable (and the corresponding revenue in the case of
commercial transactions) is initially recorded at a value equal to the present value of future cash flows plus any
transaction costs. The rate used to discount future flows is the market rate.

In the case of financial receivables, the difference between the cash and cash equivalents disbursed and the
present value of future cash flows, determined using the market interest rate, is recognized under financial
income or expense in the income statement at the time of initial recognition, unless the substance of the
transaction or contract leads to the attribution of a different nature to this component. Subsequently, the interest
income accruing on the transaction is calculated at the effective interest rate and charged to the income
statement with the value of the receivable as a contra entry.

The value of the receivables is subsequently reduced by the amounts received, both by way of principal and
interest, as well as for any write-downs to bring the receivables back to their presumed realisable value or for
losses.

The Group assumes that the effects deriving from the application of the amortized cost and the discounting back
are not relevant when the maturity of the receivables is within 12 months, also taking into account all the
contractual and substantial considerations in place on recognition of the receivable, and the transaction costs and
any difference between the initial value and the nominal value at maturity is of an insignificant amount. In this
case, discounting was omitted, the interest was calculated at nominal value and the transaction costs were
entered among deferrals and amortized on a straight-line basis over the duration of the receivable to adjust the
nominal interest income.

**_Provisions for risks and charges_**

They are set aside to cover losses or debts of certain or probable existence, whose amount or date of occurrence
could not be determined at the end of the year.

In the measurement of these provisions, the general criteria of prudence and accrual accounting are respected,
and no provision was made for generic risks without economic justification.

Contingent liabilities are recognized in the financial statements and booked under provisions when they are
likely to materialise and when the amount of the related charge can be reasonably estimated.

Any risks for which the occurrence of a liability is only possible or for which no objective forecast of the
resulting charge is possible are indicated in the explanatory notes of the financial statements without allocating
provisions for risks and charges.

Risks whose probability of occurrence appears remote are not taken into account.

**_Income taxes—Current, Prepaid and Deferred_**

Current income taxes are allocated according to the accrual principle on the basis of the tax charges resulting
from the application of the tax legislation in force and are entered among tax payables net of advances.

Deferred and prepaid taxes are determined on the temporary differences between the value attributed to the
assets and liabilities according to statutory criteria and the value attributed to the same assets and liabilities for
tax purposes.

Deferred taxes are entered in the ‘Provision for deferred taxes’, recorded under liabilities among the provisions
for risks and charges, while the prepaid taxes are recorded in the receivables from others under current assets.

Assets deriving from prepaid taxes are not recognized, in compliance with the prudence principle, if there is no
reasonable certainty of the existence, in the fiscal years in which the relative temporary differences will be
reversed, of a taxable income higher than the amount of the differences that will be cancelled. Liabilities for
deferred taxes are recognized only if there is a reasonable certainty that they will reverse in the foreseeable


-----

future. Deferred tax assets and deferred tax liabilities are valued at the estimated tax rates applicable in the year
in which the tax asset will be realised or the tax liability will be settled, based on the tax legislation established
by the provisions in force at the reporting date.

**_Accruals and deferrals_**

The portions of costs and income common to two or more fiscal years, according to the matching and accrual
basis, are recorded in these items. Based on this criterion, accruals or deferrals are recognized when the
following conditions are met:

- the contract begins in one fiscal year and ends in a subsequent one;

- the consideration for the services is contractually due in advance or in arrears with respect to services
common to two or more consecutive years;

- the amount of accruals and deferrals varies with the passage of time.

Income and charges that have accrued in full in the fiscal year to which the financial statements refer or in
subsequent ones are not included among accruals and deferrals.

**Global higher education market has shown attractive and resilient growth supported by solid structural**
**fundamentals that have been further accelerated by private spend and online penetration**

The global base of students enrolled in higher education increased from 83 million students in 1996 to over 250
million in 2022 showing a resilient 4% compound annual growth (despite several economic downturns) and
backed by solid structural fundamentals such as total population growth and share of enrolled population in
higher education. Notably, global higher education enrollment showed a 13% growth through the dot-com
bubble (1998 to 2000) and over 20% growth through the global financial crisis (2008 to 2010).

**Number of Students enrolled[52] in Higher Education Worldwide[53]** (1996-2022 | million)

Some of the key structural tailwinds in global higher education include (i) a widening gap between supply and
demand of the skills in the employment market, (ii) the need for more career-relevant degrees and (iii) the
increased relevance of lifelong learning and reskilling in the job market.

52 Number of students enrolled in tertiary education regardless of age.

53 Global Management Company, Market Report (2024), Global Management Company analysis on UIS data (2023).


-----

There is a tangible increasing demand globally for a highly educated workforce largely driven by a continuously
evolving technological landscape. In particular, the growing and accelerated need for digital skills is fuelling
demand for continuous learning and upskilling especially in constantly evolving areas of the market such as
“industry 4.0” roles (i.e., robotics, machine learning, artificial intelligence). Furthermore, and as a consequence
of the job market evolution, experienced workers are increasingly demanding continuous learning opportunities
to remain up to date in their current careers displaying a desire for learning opportunities that are self-directed,
affordable and accessible.

There have been two clearly identified vectors that have contributed to the accelerated growth of the higher
education market globally: (i) global population growth, (ii) private spend growth and (iii) development of
online education alternatives. Over the past decade the financial constraints of certain governments to cater for
incremental education needs of the population, have resulted in increased private spending in higher education
which contributed to the expansion of higher education offerings and enhanced accessibility. As a result, the
global private higher education market grew from 70 million students in 2014 to 80 million in 2021, showing a
compound annual growth rate above 3%.

Another key growth vector for the higher education market globally has been the positive evolution in online
penetration. Growth has been supported by a strong development of the technology associated with the delivery
format of the courses and an improving perception of online degrees. The effect of the COVID-19 pandemic has
further accelerated an ongoing trend of change in learning behaviours which are anticipated to have a lasting
effect on demand for more accessible and affordable higher education options. As a result, online penetration in
education globally has increased from 15% in the 2015/2016 academic year to over 25% in the 2020/2021
academic year.

**The Italian higher education market has historically demonstrated stable growth which in recent years**
**has been accelerated by online enrollments, yet graduate penetration is still well below other nations in**
**Europe due to a number of structural challenges**

The Italian higher education market is broad and developed, home to some of the oldest universities ever
established. In Italy as of the 2021/2022 academic year there are 68[56] public universities mostly located in major
urban areas. These do not have admission tests, except for specific courses (such as medicine and architecture)
and as of 2023 have average annual tuition fees of approximately €1,600[57], depending on a students’ immediate
family’s wealth. There are 20 private physical universities in Italy, with higher average tuition fees
(approximately €4,600[6] in 2023) and mostly with an admission test and/or criteria based on students’ academic
performance in high school. Online universities in Italy represent a smaller segment of 11 universities, with no
admission test (also driven by the fact that there are no limitations associated with physical space availability)

Unlike other countries, Italy also has a considerably lower share of university students who are satisfied with
their life overall (62%), a sizeable gap compared with other developed (approximately 70-75%) and developing
countries (approximately 76-82%) as of 2018[64]. In addition, the share of students considering dropping out of
university is elevated in Italy at 36%, in contrast with other developed countries, approximately 30-35%, and
developing countries, approximately 8-20%[13] over the same period. Overall, this has resulted in the lowest share
of bachelor’s degree students in Italy who completed any tertiary level education on time, at 21% in contrast
with 48% average of France, Spain, the U.S. and the U.K. One of the main reasons behind the gap, according to
students, is that the learning experience in university in Italy is perceived as difficult and with low practical
applications due to certain structural challenges in the physical university system.

The Italian physical university structural issues are attributable to (i) a population fragmented into many smallmedium urban areas, only a portion of which host an in-person university, which results in university attendance
being expensive and cumbersome for students working at the same time, (ii) the Italian public university system
having sizable gaps in terms of fundings and agility to innovate and (iii) the outdated and highly theoretical
approach of physical universities leading to students’ dissatisfaction and longer time for graduation.

increased their relevance in the market, representing 14% of the total undergraduate population in Italy with

2015/2016 academic year and even more remarkable when considering that this channel did not exist prior to

**Clear regulatory endorsement of online universities in Italy and the competitive landscape of the Italian**
**online higher education market today**

Online universities were created in Italy upon the regulatory endorsement to fill the structural gap of the
physical university system. On April 17, 2003, the Italian University Education and Research Ministry, together
with the Minister for Innovation and Technology, opened the higher education market to online universities, in
an effort to increase the number of people holding a higher education degree and offer a more flexible and
affordable path to students in comparison with physical universities while granting degrees of equal legal value.

Since the opening of the online Italian higher education market in 2003, 11 private online universities were
established, with online universities enrolling their first students in 2006. The online university market is
structurally closed to new entrants, as no further licenses are currently expected to be issued. In particular, the
restriction for the establishment of online universities in Italy is usually extended every three years, with the
publication of the Ministerial Decree governing Italian universities’ academic planning. The latest Ministerial

Decree published in March 2021 (Decree n. 289 of March 25, 2021) confirmed the restriction until the
2023/2024 academic year. The provisions of the decree shall apply until the ministerial decree establishing the
general guidelines for the 2024-2026 academic period is issued, which as of the date of this Offering
Memorandum is still under discussion before the competent ministry. Online higher education activities are
subject to extensive regulation and must obtain and maintain several authorizations. Individual courses are
subject to various accreditation requirements from the MIUR in order for them to carry the same legal
recognition as courses offered from a traditional university. Courses also must undergo a review process with
the MIUR every three years with institutions undergoing review every five years in order to maintain licensing.
Additionally, starting from the 2021/2022 academic year, online universities were required to reduce their
student to faculty ratio by approximately a third pursuant to DM 2021, further increasing barriers for smaller
competitors who lack the resources to increase their teaching staff.

Multiversity, which encompasses three of the fastest growing online universities (Pegaso, Mercatorum, and San
Raffaelle), has quickly become the largest university group in Italy (including physical and online) with enrolled
students reaching approximately 151,000 in the 2022/2023 academic year (+32% compound annual growth rate
from the 2018/2019 academic year to 2022/2023). Despite the strong recent growth, Multiversity still accounts
for only 8% of the market share in the 2022/2023 academic year in a highly fragmented market of 99
universities in Italy.

**Online universities are expected to continue driving growth in the Italian higher education market**

Online universities in Italy have activated a demand for higher education that was formerly unmet through
attracting students that would have otherwise not enrolled in higher education.

The overall enrolled undergraduate base in Italy is expected to grow from approximately 2.0 million in the
2023/2024 academic year to about 2.3 million in the 2027/2028 academic year, representing a compound annual
growth rate of about 4%. Over the same period, the online market is expected to grow on average 15% annually,
reaching approximately 0.6 million enrolled students by the 2027/2028 academic year, while the physical
enrollments are expected to grow at a more modest pace of about 1% per year. This would represent a notable
increase of 8 percentage points in online penetration, reaching 24% penetration in the 2027/2028 academic year
from 16% penetration in the 2023/2024 academic year.

Some of the key drivers for the demand for university graduates in the job market in Italy include increased
professionalization of the small and medium enterprises (“SMEs”), as well as increasing requirements for
degrees in both public administration roles and for independent professionals. There is a rapid
professionalization trend in SMEs, as of 2021 representing 53% of the Italian working population, resulting in
high demand for university graduates. Public administration roles, which make up 12% of the Italian working
population, are increasingly either requiring or ascribing higher value to having a university degree for the same
period[81]. In addition, independent professionals who currently represents 19% of the Italian working population
are increasingly incentivized (driven by higher compensation and career progression) to have a higher education
degree[82].

The growing inflows in the Italian online university market are supported by growth across these student
categories with the majority to be driven by the latecomer category which is expected to account for about 62%
of the inflows in the 2023/2024 academic year, followed by 1[st] year MSc (25%), and freshmen (11%), and the
double degree students (2%).

The double degree students represent a new category of students in the market, enabled by the double degree
law, which was approved in April 2022 (Law 12 April 2022, n. 33) and allows students who are already enrolled
in a university (physical or online) degree to enroll in a second degree simultaneously. According to MIUR, dual
enrollment should be facilitated by universities and is permitted as long as the two degrees do not belong to the
same class and to medical specialization courses, and are not the same undergraduate, graduate, or master’s
degree at two different universities. The 2022/2023 academic year was the first year such dual enrollment was
permitted. As such, double degree student inflows are expected to grow from a relatively small inflow today to
making up 6% of the total undergraduate student inflows by the 2027/2028 academic year, representing a
compound annual growth rate of 55%. Freshmen inflows are expected to grow at a compounded annual rate of
15% during this period, supported by a higher share of the population graduating high-school and the increased
willingness to go to university, as well as higher interest in attending university online. Latecomers continue to
grow on the back of higher interest in online universities and the continued increase in the share of the
population willing to pay over €1,000 per year for attending online university. Overall, the latecomer inflows are
expected to grow at compound annual rate of 13% during this period. Finally, the 1[st] year MSc students are
supported by a steadily increasing number of graduates from bachelor courses and a stable outlook for the share
of graduates continuing with MSc programs.

**BUSINESS**

**Overview**

**_General_**

Established in 2006, Multiversity is the leading university in the Italian online higher education market with
approximately 151,000 undergraduate enrolled students (and approximately 206,000 enrolled students in total)
for the 2022/2023 academic year. Based on the number of university students enrolled for the 2022/2023
academic year, the company has an estimated market share in the Italian online academic education of 57%, an
estimated market share in the Italian academic education (across both physical and online universities) of 8%[85]
and a student satisfaction rate of 98%[86]. Multiversity also has a leading role in the foundation of UNITED (the
first association of Italian online universities). It operates several education assets, and in particular:

  - Online universities: Multiversity operates three fully licensed private online universities in Italy with
MIUR accreditations: Università Telematica Pegaso S.r.l. (“Pegaso”), Universitas Mercatorum
(“Mercatorum”) and Università Telematica San Raffaele Roma S.r.l. (“San Raffaele”). It provides a
student centric proposition with a wide array of undergraduate and post graduate courses to
approximately 206,000 students for the 2022/2023 academic year and is supported by a strong
professor base (10 Multiversity professors have been included in the “Top Scientists – World Top 2%”
ranking from Stanford University). Degrees awarded at the end of academic courses have the same
legal value as degrees issued by traditional universities. 97.4% of Multiversity’s revenue for the year
ended December 31, 2023 was generated by the university segment.

  - Non-academic courses and certifications: Multiversity has also expanded into a complementary nonuniversity education segment, mainly focusing on: (i) B2B and B2C executive education through Sole
24 Ore Formazione S.p.A. (“Sole 24 Ore Formazione”), (ii) digital skills through Aulab S.r.l.
(“Aulab”), a coding factory, which delivers short term courses for software developers, and (iii) a
certification entity, Certipass S.r.l. (“Certipass”). 2.3% of Multiversity’s revenue for the year ended
December 31, 2023 was generated by the non-academic education segment.

  - Other assets: Multiversity also operates a number of academies offering courses on specific subjects
(e.g. communication, marketing and law) as well as other assets (e.g. Principe di Napoli, which
provides gastronomy and tourism higher education, or Benecon, a research center promoted by the
Campania Region). 0.3% of Multiversity’s revenues for the year ended December 31, 2023 were
generated by the other assets segment.

Multiversity delivers its services through a proprietary online platform that produces its e-learning content,
which is developed in-house. In addition, Multiversity is also a pioneer in the use of artificial intelligence in
education, in particular for marketing purposes and for the development of new use cases (such as its Tutor
Chatbot and Exam Generator applications).

**_Online universities_**

Pegaso is Multiversity’s largest university. Approximately 140,000 students were enrolled in Pegaso’s online
courses for the 2022/2023 academic year. Pegaso offers a range of both undergraduate and postgraduate courses,
and in particular eight undergraduate bachelor’s degrees, five specialist master’s degrees, one single cycle fiveyear degree and 158 courses, including postgraduate master’s courses and higher education and specialization
courses for professionals and high school graduates. Pegaso also offers individual certifications and gives
students the possibility to undertake single examinations for each course module upon payment of a fee without
having to complete the full course.

Multiversity’s second key institution, Mercatorum, is 66.67% owned by Multiversity, with the remaining
33.33% stake held by Unioncamere, the Italian Union of Chambers of Commerce, Industry, Crafts and
Agriculture, which is the public body that unifies and institutionally represents the Italian system of chambers of

Multiversity’s third primary institution in terms of revenue, San Raffaele, became part of the Group in 2022, and

**_Non-academic courses and certifications_**

In relation to the non-university education segment, Multiversity operates Sole 24 Ore Formazione in
partnership with Il Sole 24 Ore S.p.A. (with Multiversity holding a majority stake of 85%) to deliver B2B and
B2C executive master's courses to professionals and young graduates. As part of the B2B offerings, Multiversity
also offers compulsory courses, soft skills, industry and managerial training to corporates. These courses can be
offered as off-the shelf, co-designed or fully customized. The B2B courses can vary in length, while the B2C
courses typically last one to six months. The new partnership benefits from a top level academic and scientific
training offer, thanks to the support of the universities that are part of the Group as well as the support and the
strong brand recognition of the Il Sole 24 Ore group (owning the 15% of Sole 24 Ore Formazione), one of the
leading finance newspapers in Italy, which provides content to readers, professionals, businesses, and
institutions on topics of economics, finance, and management. Additionally, Multiversity owns 60.61% of
Aulab, a player in the digital training sector for developers with a high placement rate of its students thanks to
an effective training model for coding and IT education, an efficient placement platform and partnerships with
top companies. This training model requires no pre-requisites and typically lasts from three to 6 months. In
addition to training, Aulab also designs and develops websites, IT platforms and software applications. The nonuniversity segment also includes Certipass, a provider of international EIPASS certifications for digital
competences and IT skills.

**_Academies and other assets_**

The Group also includes a number of academies established through collaboration agreements between Pegaso,
Mercatorum and San Raffaele and their respective commercial partners, covering a wide range of specialist
subjects such as marketing, communications and media and teaching. Other assets include Principe di Napoli
S.a.r.l. (“Principe di Napoli”), established in February 2019 by Pegaso in partnership with Mercatorum
(holding 90% and 10% stakes, respectively) as a center for higher education and specialization in the sectors of
gastronomy and tourism. Apart from the Postgraduate School in Legal Professions (as further described below),
Principe di Napoli is one of the few institution within Multiversity to hold on premise courses. Additionally, in
December 2023, the Group acquired a minority stake in Materias S.r.l., an incubator of scientific research
activities engaged in identifying innovative ideas in the field of advanced materials, primarily generated from
the academic sector.

Multiversity also operates a publishing entity and companies dedicated to research, which are mostly ancillary
and in support of the three universities. Almost the entirety of its operations are located in Italy, with some
limited operations in Malta (Pegaso International). It also has collaboration agreements with several partners in
Italy for the development and delivery of specialized courses in a multitude of subjects, made available through
its three universities.

In order to support their online offering, Multiversity’s institutions have an extensive network of approximately
1,000[88] e-learning center points (the “ELCPs”) as of December 31, 2023. The ELCPs provide information to
prospective and current students about the various institutions and serve as orientation centers for new students
throughout the entire duration of the course they undertake. The ELCP Points performed orientation activities
for approximately 61% of Multiversity’s institution’s new students as of December 31, 2023; however, the

**_Financial Performance_**

Multiversity’s revenues for the financial year ended December 31, 2023 amounted to €419.9 million, as
compared to €332.0 million for the prior financial year ended December 31, 2022 (an increase of 26.5%).
Enrolled undergraduate students at Pegaso, Mercatorum and San Raffaele increased by approximately 28% in
the 2022/2023 academic year with respect to the 2021/2022 academic year.

In addition, Adjusted EBITDA generated for the year ended December 31, 2023 was €247.2 million as
compared to €200.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2022 (an increase of 23.6%). Adjusted EBITDA
margin for the year ended December 31, 2023 was 58.9%, as compared to 60.2% for the year ended December
31, 2022.

Furthermore, Adjusted Operating Free Cash Flow generated for the year ended December 31, 2023 was €226.0
million, as compared to €157.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2022 (an increase of 43%). Adjusted
Cash Conversion for the year ended December 31, 2023 was 91%, as compared to 79% for the year ended
December 31, 2022 (an increase of 12%).

**_Business Model_**

Multiversity’s business model is based on a student-centric offering of a flexible learning experience and access
to teaching content through its proprietary and technologically advanced e-learning platform. Multiversity’s
universities address specific unmet demand in the market for a flexible path to an undergraduate degree, whilst
catering to specific professions for postgraduate continuous learning.

Revenues are mainly driven by tuition fees paid by students, which contributed to 75%[90] of Multiversity’s
revenues. Almost the entirety of tuition fees is self-funded by students, with less than 1% paid through
scholarships. The levels of tuition fees in turn depend on the number of students, the nature or class of degree
undertaken, the year of enrollment, the type of course and the student’s selected enrollment channel, amongst
other factors. Undergraduate degrees, which are multi-year courses (three-year bachelor’s degree plus a twoyear specialist master’s degree, or a single-cycle five-year degree), are a recurring multi-year revenue stream for
the term of the program (consisting of both the tuition fees and any other ancillary fees), which has an average
course length of approximately 2.4 years. Approximately 30% of Multiversity's graduates who have completed
three-year undergraduate degree courses wish to continue their education and apply to enroll in two-year
specialist master’s degree and master’s degree courses with the same institution.

On the other hand, one-year postgraduate courses (i.e. second level master’s which may be undertaken by
students who have already completed a three year undergraduate bachelor’s degree plus a two year specialist
master’s degree or a single-cycle five year degree), together with higher education courses and specialization
courses, provide a one-off tuition fee payment per student, accounting for 6% of Multiversity’s revenues for the
financial year ended December 31, 2023. Various other services offered to students provide additional revenue
such as fees payable in order to take examinations in an alternative location, and certificates; such additional
services accounted for approximately 14% of Multiversity’s revenues for the financial year ended December 31,
2023. Single exams contributed to 1% of Multiversity’s revenues for the year ended December 31, 2023. The
non-academic business segment (including Certipass, Aulab and Sole 24 Ore Formazione) accounted for
approximately 2% of Multiversity revenues for the year ended December 31, 2023.

The other assets segment (which include Principe di Napoli, Benecon and other smaller companies) accounted
for 0.3% of Multiversity’s revenues for the year ended December 31, 2023.

With respect to student orientation, around 61% of new students as of December 31, 2023 (contributing to 62%
of commercial revenues for the 2022/2023 academic year) across Pegaso, Mercatorum and San Raffaele partook
in orientation activities at the approximately 1,000 ELCPs that make up Multiversity’s national network.
Approximately 39% of students as of December 31, 2023 (contributing to 38% of commercial revenues for the
2022/2023 academic year) were reached through traditional marketing methods, e.g. billboards and TV
advertising campaigns on both private and public Italian channels, as well as through its extensive online
presence on social media and online advertising, thereby gaining access to the widest possible audience and
delivering tangible results, with an increase in new leads of 50% in 2023 compared to 2022. Multiversity has
established a nation-wide presence, with approximately 100 exam venues located in prestigious and historical
buildings, along with a strong online social community and proprietary technology platforms for online classes,
exams and tutoring.

Multiversity’s growth strategy is predominantly based on expanding volumes by increasing market penetration
within the population, whilst selectively increasing its course offering, its brand awareness, digital marketing
practices and _ad hoc_ orientation services to prospective students as well as by entering into commercial
agreements and partnerships.

Additionally, revenues are driven by increases in our tuition fees taking into account inflation and other
commercial considerations. For example, Multiversity increased its undergraduate tuition fees for newly
enrolling students by approximately 8% on average for the 2022/2023 academic year, as compared to the prior
academic year. See further “—Competitive Strengths” and “Business Strategy” below.

The main objective underpinning Multiversity’s business strategy is to consolidate its market position and
strengthen its position as the leading entirely online education group in the Italian market, employing both
Business-to-Consumer and Business-to-Business marketing strategies in order to target an ever-wider audience
of students. See further “—Competitive Strengths” and “—Business Strategy” below.

**Competitive Strengths**

**Multiversity operates in the sizeable Italian higher education market which is highly attractive due to its**
**structurally low graduate penetration, providing online universities an opportunity to fill the education**
**deficit**

Multiversity benefits from operating in the sizeable Italian higher education market (1.9 million undergraduate
students in Italy across online and traditional universities for the 2022/2023 academic year compared to 1.8
million undergraduate students for the 2020/2021 academic year)[91], where graduate penetration lags behind
other European countries. University graduate penetration[92] in Italy stood at only 29% in 2020 (increasing from
25% in 2015), compared to 44% on average for the EU, 56% for the U.K., 49% for France, 47% for Spain and
35% for Germany for the same period.[93] This low penetration is due to a number of structural factors in Italy
described further below, the combination of which allows online universities such as Multiversity to fill the
education deficit.

Accessibility to physical universities in Italy remains challenging due to a number of factors, including (i) a high
geographic dispersion of the population in Italy when compared to other major European countries, with 52% of
Italians living in non-metropolitan areas[94] (compared to an average of 29% for Spain, the U.K., France and
Germany)[95] and 77% living in municipalities with 100,000 or fewer inhabitants[96] as of 2022; and (ii) a high
concentration of physical universities in Italy in larger cities, leaving 52%[97] of provinces in Italy without a
physical university.[98]
