The gap in public expenditure is aggravated by a student housing deficit that creates significant cost pressure on
students who study outside of their hometown (which represents 46% of the 1.9 million undergraduate student
population in Italy for the 2022/2023 academic year)[100], with only between 8-10% of off-campus housing
demand in 2023 covered by public and private student housing (significantly lower than an average of
approximately 20% of demand covered in the EU)[101], resulting in a total cost of education (including rent costs,
tuition, food and learning materials) that is around 58-72% of the median disposable income in Italy of
approximately 23,000 as of 2023[102].

Further, the physical university education system in Italy (including its curriculum and teaching methodology) is
considered by many to be outdated and broadly disconnected from students’ needs in terms of content, delivery
and flexibility. In 2018, Italy had the lowest student satisfaction rate compared to other developed[103] or
developing[104] countries (62% in Italy compared to 76-82% in developing countries and 70-75% in the
developed countries for the same period).[105] 57% of students in Italy as of 2018 who dropped out cited studyrelated issues as their reason for leaving[106].[107] Overall, these factors and the other limitations mentioned above
contribute to significantly lower graduation success rates in Italy compared to other countries, with only 21% of
graduate students[108] in Italy in 2022 graduating on time and 53% graduating within three years of the end of

These structural reasons for low penetration and incentives to pursue higher education create an opportunity for
online universities to bridge the sizable gap by eliminating the need for relocation and reducing the total cost of
higher education while providing flexible and quality education. Online university enrollment in Italy now
captures approximately 13.7% of total higher education enrollment in Italy for the 2022/2023 academic year,
increasing from approximately 10.4% for the 2020/2021 academic year, as students move towards digital
delivery, with students reporting higher overall rates of satisfaction at online universities such as Multiversity,
along with better retention and on time graduation.[110] See “—Multiversity is the leading online education
_platform in Europe and Italy, with a fit for purpose value proposition, providing legally equivalent education_
_with strong placement outcomes at an attractive pricing.” The addressable market[111] in Italy is also_
underpenetrated, large, and growing, standing at approximately 1 million students in 2019 and 1.5 million
students in 2023.

**_Government endorsement of online education in Italy to fill the structural gap through a limited number of_**
**_degree awarding licenses and extensive regulation_**

In order to make higher education more accessible to a wider share of population, the Italian government opened
the Italian higher education market to online competition in 2003, effectively creating a public-private
partnership to help address the structural gap. In an effort to keep the quality of education elevated, only eleven
online university licenses with full degree awarding power have been awarded thus far and as a consequence no
additional licenses have been granted since 2006. The restriction for the establishment of online universities in
Italy is usually extended every 3 years through the publication of ministerial decrees, the latest of which
confirmed the restriction until the 2023/2024 academic year. This provides a stable regulatory environment and
strong tailwinds for incumbent online universities such as Multiversity.

At the same time, Multiversity’s activities are also subject to extensive regulation and obtaining and maintaining
authorizations which can be onerous for new entrants. Individual courses offered by Multiversity’s academic
institutions are subject to accreditation requirements from the MIUR in order for them to provide the same legal
value as courses offered from a physical university, and courses must undergo a strict review process every
three years with institutions undergoing review every five years in order to maintain licensing. The regulatory
requirements, amongst others, reducing student to faculty ratio by a third pursuant to Decree 1154/2021, further
support the position of leading providers like Multiversity as opposed to smaller institutions who may lack the
resources to increase their teaching staff and whose profitability and operations would be impaired by adhering
to the regulation.

Lastly, 99% of tuition fees paid to Multiversity as of the 2022/2023 academic year are self-funded by students,
meaning that Multiversity is not dependent on public funding.

**_Multiversity is the leading online education platform in Europe and Italy, with a fit for purpose value_**
**_proposition, providing legally equivalent education with strong placement outcomes at an attractive pricing_**

Multiversity enjoys a clear leadership position in the Italian online university market by number of
undergraduate students due to its combination of operational expertise, extensive course offering, a fit for
purpose value proposition and continuous quality control that results in strong outcomes and student satisfaction
at an affordable price. Multiversity is the largest online university in Italy by number of undergraduate for the
2022/2023 academic year.[112] It is also the largest for-profit education group in the EU by number of
undergraduate and graduate students enrolled as of 2022.[113]

Online universities provide an accessible and flexible value proposition compared to physical universities.
Flexibility and time saving are the top reason that students choose an online university education, with 83% of
students citing this as a reason for their choice in 2023.[114]

Multiversity’s academic offering is provided at an affordable price-point compared to other online and physical
universities in terms of tuition fees and overall cost of education. The average annual tuition at Multiversity for
the 2023/2024 academic year was lower than its online competitors at approximately €2,000 per student
(compared to €3,200-€3,400 per student for E-Campus Università, €2,700-€2,900 per student for Università
Niccolò Cusano and €2,000-€2,200 per student for Guglielmo Marconi as of 2023).[115] The overall cost of online
universities is also significantly lower than physical universities, in particular for students who study outside of
their hometown. The total cost of a degree[116] for students at online universities was €8,000-€10,000 as of 2023,
which is up to 7.5x lower than the total cost of studying at a physical university[117] for students attending
university outside of their hometown.[118] While online universities tend to have higher tuition fees on average
compared to physical universities, students save on rent costs (comprising about 50% of total education costs at
physical universities) and other costs such as commuting and exam costs (comprising about 40% of total
education costs at physical universities) and are able to graduate on average 0.8 years quicker, all as of 2023.[119]

_Public Information, Company Information._

**_Fully invested, scalable proprietary technology platform with in-house developed content designed to provide_**
**_high-quality user experience, complemented by a capillary physical network of orientation and exam centers_**

The technological platform developed by Multiversity over the years represents a clear competitive advantage.
Multiversity is a large online student community in Italy, with on average approximately 50,000 students on its
platform at any given time and 2 million daily page visits. User experience has always been at the center of the
development of Multiversity's advanced IT platform, which was fully digital from its inception. Students are
able to access all video lessons, class materials and mock exams, interact via video conference with professors
and tutors, and even attend exams online, all through user-friendly Pegaso, Mercatorum and San Raffaele
websites or mobile apps and personalized student dashboards.

Multiversity creates its content for these platforms with a focus on creating a high-quality user experience: while
professors create the content, they are supported throughout by Multiversity IT staff, which includes 40 content
delivery FTEs, who ensure that materials produced are optimized to be deployed across all its channels. The
company has developed its platform completely in-house, achieving a strong back-end able to deliver
seamlessly across all platforms and devices. Multiversity has seven recording rooms for content production,
with over 2,500 hours of content produced annually and 100% of classes recorded on video. Multiversity is able
to create new courses in a relatively short period of time, which is typically only one month for masters courses
and six months for undergraduate courses[120]. Students can enjoy an on-demand library of approximately 30,000
hours of content typically provided in 30-60 minute clips, covering 40 undergraduate courses and 318 other
courses including post-graduate and masters' courses.

Multiversity’s platform, in addition to leveraging the latest technology available such as facial recognition to
confirm student identity, offers advanced proprietary features such as a suggestion tool for its students (enabled
by artificial intelligence and machine learning) that prompts highly relevant content to each individual based on
their career path, grades and progress, and a new generative AI University Assistant Tool that leverages OpenAI
to provide students with 24/7 support through a chatbot exclusively trained with specific course content
(selected by professors), further assisting their studies by answering complex questions about their courses with
an accuracy rate surpassing 99% for the 2022/2023 academic year.

Multiversity’s technology platform is complemented by a physical network of ELCPs and exam locations that
allow extensive coverage of the entire country. Proximity and ease of access to local infrastructure are key
determinants for students when choosing between traditional forms of higher education and online and, within
the latter, selecting one university over another. ELCPs play a critical role in the Italian online university system

**_Sustained organic growth with highly visible revenue profile, coupled with high profitability levels and cash_**
**_conversion_**

Multiversity, by benefiting from the positive structural tailwinds described above and by delivering a strong
student centric offering, has a track record of impressive revenue, profitability and cash conversion growth. For
the year ended December 31, 2023, value of production was €419.9 million, Adjusted EBITDA was €247.2
million and operating free cash flow was €193.3 million, compared to €255.4 million, €150.1 million and
€139.3 million, respectively, for the year ended December 31, 2021, representing a compound annual growth
rate of 28.2%, 28.3% and 17.8%, respectively, mostly from organic growth. Excluding the revenue contributable
to the acquisition of San Raffaele on October 4, 2022, equal to €5.2 million for the year ended December 31,
2022 (limited to the two months consolidation) and to €30.2 for the year ended December 31, 2023,
Multiversity’s value of production increased by a compound annual growth rate of 23.1% over this two-year
period.

Multiversity’s organic growth has largely been driven by undergraduate enrollment. New undergraduate
enrollments have continued to grow over the years, increasing from around 50,000 in the 2017/2018 academic
year to around 151,000 in the 2022/2023 academic year. Undergraduate enrollment tends to have a longer
duration compared to graduate enrollment, with a strong conversion rate (40% of graduates from 3-year degree
programs apply for 1- or 2-year master’s degrees). These dynamics together with a low churn rate are of
particular relevance given that approximately 90% of the Group’s revenues for the year ended December 31,
2023 were generated from undergraduate programs[123], thus allowing strong visibility on future top-line
evolution.

Approximately 63% of Multiversity’s revenues for the financial year ended December 31, 2023 were already
secured as of January 1, 2023, primarily due to new enrollments for the 2022/2023 academic year between
August 2022 and December 2022 and to existing students’ enrollments for the 2022/2023 academic year,
while approximately 37% of revenues for the same period were derived from new students enrolled from

**_High-quality and experienced management team, with strong execution track record and supported by an_**
**_internationally reputable advisory board and sponsor_**

Multiversity benefits from its highly experienced and committed management team, with deep education knowhow and relevant external professional experience. The management team is composed of both individuals
within the corporate headquarters and independent academic departments, which is designed to provide the
optimal mix between strategic vision, planning and control, and academic requirements. Multiversity's
management team is supported by the expertise of Multiversity’s recently established Advisory Board, which is
comprised of 10 internationally reputable professionals and prominent leaders in their respective fields, who
combine institutional experience and connectivity along with strategic vision, representing a key milestone in
Multiversity’s continuous journey towards quality higher education and research. Multiversity’s management
team is further supported by the strong and continuing commitment of CVC. CVC has a proven track record of
growing leading education groups across the world with a well-established presence in Italy since 1987. It has
made 13 investments in Italy over the last 10 years with a total equity investment of around €3.5 billion.

In recent years, Multiversity has successfully broadened its product offering by entering the non-university
market through (i) the partnership with Sole 24 ORE Formazione, a provider of executive education programs
with strong brand recognition, an established corporate community in Italy and over 20 years of experience in
business education; and (ii) the acquisition of Aulab, an Italian provider of coding skills programs and a
reference player in the Italian digital training sector.

With its expertise in online university education and its comprehensive technology platform and method of
content delivery, Multiversity is well-positioned to expand into the non-university market and capture an even
greater market share in Italy and beyond.

**Business Strategy**

We pursue the following strategy to maintain and strengthen Multiversity’s position as the leading Italian online
higher education group.

**_Continue to consolidate Multiversity’s market position and address the large and structurally under-_**
**_penetrated Italian higher education market_**

The Italian higher education market remains structurally under-penetrated compared to other European and
other developed nations. Multiversity’s offering aims to tap into unmet demand in Italy across all student
categories. In particular, Multiversity will continue to target its historically core segment of latecomers, which is
comprised of individuals who are in the workforce but have not completed higher education, along with growing
its share of first year masters’ students and the younger and more resilient segment of incoming undergraduate
freshmen who are just coming out of secondary education.

Multiversity’s commitment to deliver an accessible and quality online education experience to its students is the
foundation of our strategy and mission. We will continue to offer Multiversity students flexibility and consistent
support during their academic careers, through a compelling student-centric learning experience that allows
students to have access to higher education regardless of where they are located and at an affordable price
compared to physical universities and other online universities. These factors facilitate higher graduation,
student satisfaction and retention rates compared to Multiversity’s competitors.


-----

The key drivers of this compelling proposition include the quality and breadth of Multiversity’s offering (which
is available to students on demand given that 100% percent of lectures are recorded and available for students to
access at their own time); an engaging user experience delivered through a proprietary and differentiated
cutting-edge technology platform, complete with a personalized student dashboard and virtual support; strong
brand recognition; a capillary network of physical ECLPs and exam centers; and attractive pricing.

Additionally, in line with the 2030 Agenda for the Sustainable Development Goals, we remain committed to
delivering an inclusive and accessible education, promoting opportunities of continuous learning for everyone,
and facilitating access to job opportunities for Multiversity students.

**_Continue to invest in academic quality and research, improving the student learning experience along with_**
**_facilitating effective placement into the job market_**

The breadth of Multiversity’s offering is one of the factors behind its success. Multiversity’s commitment to the
continuing investment in and improving of academic quality and research represents a core priority of our
strategy. We intend to continue growing Multiversity’s base of professors and focus on attracting highly
respectable professors with strong academic backgrounds, high publication rates and high rankings within their
respective fields.

Additionally, the level and quality of Multiversity’s educational offering is continuously monitored through a
comprehensive quantitative framework through which we track over 25 KPIs, which are actively monitored to
ensure the effectiveness of Multiversity’s educational offering and student placement. The framework operates
in three-steps: (i) first, we analyze an inbound student’s profile using demographic and education background
data; (ii) second, we measure the effectiveness of the delivery of Multiversity’s in-classroom and out-ofclassroom educational offering by tracking faculty excellence (such as publications, citations and research) and
learning outcome metrics (such as graduation, re-enrollment, churn rate and satisfaction); and (iii) lastly, we
measure post-degree placement performance, including employment rates and yearly salaries. This holistic
framework is critical to the ongoing development of Multiversity’s educational offering and supporting the
delivery of educational outcomes and high satisfaction to Multiversity students.

A number of further opportunities to enhance the overall student learning experience are generated by
developments in AI. Multiversity has already launched certain AI tools and services, including a Tutor Chatbot,
and will remain committed to innovation and investment through AI in augmentation of curriculum
development, compliance with standards, automatization of support services and other areas.

Beyond investments in academia, we believe Multiversity has the ability to further leverage its cutting-edge
technological platform to deliver educational content in a streamlined, intuitive and efficient manner within and
beyond its core education segments. Multiversity’s technological platform, which is supported by an internal IT
team with full back- and front-end capabilities, is proprietary and scalable. All of Multiversity’s library content,
consisting of over 30,000 hours of video across 40 undergraduate courses and 300 other courses including postgraduate and master’s courses, is produced in-house with a 1-6 month time-to-market, from designing a course
to making it available to students.

**_Maximize operating and financial performance_**

We continuously monitor and evaluate Multiversity’s operational performance to identify opportunities for
enhancement and to capitalize on embedded growth.

Multiversity continues to place significant emphasis on managing its costs efficiently, benefiting from higher
operating leverage and maintaining operational flexibility. This efficient production capability, together with
Multiversity’s current and relevant content library and proprietary platform, support Multiversity’s scalable
business model and sustained organic growth. We believe that Multiversity’s strong growth, combined with its
limited capital expenditure requirements, high cash conversion capabilities, and strong profitability margins,
will continue to generate significant cash flows to enable operational deleveraging.

We also seek to continue to generate tuition fee growth above cost inflation. Multiversity’s value proposition is
accessible at an affordable price, as Multiversity’s average tuition fee of €2,000 for the 2023/2024 academic
year is below both the average of Multiversity’s competitors and the average price students are prepared to pay
for online undergraduate university education. When combined with growing demand for online education,


-----

Multiversity’s strong brand awareness and reputation provide us with the opportunity to continue to grow our
revenues organically while sustaining our margins.

**_Pursue opportunities to grow selectively beyond Multiversity’s core undergraduate education segments and_**
**_online delivery model, leveraging the Group’s existing capabilities and integration track-record_**

We will continue to assess and pursue opportunities to grow beyond the core university segment by leveraging
Multiversity’s brand and capabilities, as well as through Multiversity’s existing non-university education
platform (including the provision of B2B/B2C executive education through the Sole 24 ORE Formazione
partnership and Multiversity’s Aulab coding factory) and selectively pursuing growth opportunities to further
broaden the reach of Multiversity’s business model.

In particular, we have identified three strategic initiatives for potential international expansion:

  - **Bolt-on acquisitions: Multiversity considers select opportunities for expansion through bolt-on**
acquisitions on an opportunistic basis, such as acquiring physical or online universities. Over recent
years, Multiversity has demonstrated its M&A capabilities with a successful execution track-record and
established processes for the efficient integration of acquired companies within the Group.

  - **Organic growth and partnerships: Multiversity has identified opportunities to expand into select**
Mediterranean countries, to leverage the Pegaso International brand and to establish partnerships with
local universities to offer an EU-recognized education in countries with a high propensity of emigration
to Italy and other countries in the European Mediterranean region, contributing to faster organic
expansion.

  - **Digital partnerships: Given its proprietary technological platform, we believe that Multiversity has**
the opportunity to form digital partnerships with education providers in developing countries to offer
technical support and online platforms, marketing strategy and other services to deliver university
content locally.

Within Italy, Multiversity's growth strategy will be focused on (i) consolidation of its university business
through the opportunistic acquisition of digital universities and the pursuit of physical opportunities, while
seeking to move towards a hybrid model and (ii) the expansion of its non-university offering synergistically,
through which it aims to strengthen its value proposition, widen its course offering and increase its presence in
the B2C/B2B continuous learning space.

**_History_**

The Italian inter-Ministerial Decree (issued jointly by the MIUR and the Italian Ministry of Technological
Innovation) of April 17, 2003 paved the way for the establishment of private online universities in Italy. The
decree was aimed at increasing the percentage of Italians holding a bachelor’s degree (at the time, amongst the
lowest in Europe). Pegaso was founded in 2006 as a non-commercial entity, having been licensed by the
Ministerial Decree of the MUIR of April 20, 2006, and launched its first two degree programs, one being a three
year bachelor’s degree and the other a single-cycle five year degree.

By 2010, Pegaso had more than 200 post-graduate degree and post-graduate diploma courses, and by the 201213 academic year, had up to 30,000 enrolled students.

By 2015, Pegaso had over 65 examination centers in Italy. Pegaso further expanded its offering through the
acquisition of the majority stake in Mercatorum and founded Pegaso International Ltd. based in Malta. By 2019,
Multiversity’s institutions had over 100,000 enrolled students.

In 2019, CVC acquired 50% of the share capital of Multiversity from the founder, Mr. Danilo Iervolino, and
Pegaso transformed into a private corporation in the form of a limited liability company (see “Regulation—
_Transformation of Pegaso into a private corporation”). The Principe di Napoli campus was also launched in the_
same year. At the time of these activities, Multiversity had over 100,000 students enrolled. Since CVC’s
investment in 2019, there has been a significant increase in enrolled students, paired with a greater academic
offering and the appointment of highly experienced management.

In 2021, Paganini, a Luxembourg company indirectly controlled by CVC, entered into a sale and purchase
agreement pursuant to which Paganini BidCo was designated as buyer to acquire the 50% of the share capital of


-----

Multiversity S.r.l. from Mr. Danilo Iervolino. Prior to this acquisition, on November 4, 2019, Paganini had
acquired from MultiSpa 50% of the share capital of Multiversity S.r.l. through a wholly equity financed
investment.

On July 22, 2022, the Perimeter Assets merged into Multiversity S.r.l., with accounting and tax effects
backdated to January 1, 2022. On the same date, the incorporating company (Multiversity S.r.l.) changed its
legal form from a limited liability company to a joint stock company, thus becoming Multiversity S.p.A. (the
Target of the Acquisition contemplated herein).

On September 16, 2022, Multiversity acquired 60.61% of Aulab, a company active in the training of software
developers, which also designs and develops websites, IT platforms and software applications.

On October 4, 2022, Multiversity acquired 100% of the share capital of Società di Gestione e Partecipazione
dell’Università Telematica San Raffaele Roma S.r.l., a company that serves as the promoting entity of San
Raffaele, an academic institution that delivers courses mainly related to biomedical and healthcare sciences.

On October 3, 2022, Multiversity entered into an investment and shareholders’ agreement for the establishment
of a partnership with Il Sole 24 Ore S.p.A., one of Italy’s leading finance newspapers, to operate Sole 24 Ore
Formazione, which delivers B2B and B2C executive master's courses to professionals and young graduates. In
accordance with the provisions of the investment and shareholders’ agreement, Sole 24 Ore Formazione was
incorporated by Il Sole 24 Ore S.p.A. on October 3, 2022, and, on November 9, 2022, Multiversity acquired
from Il Sole 24 Ore S.p.A. a participation equal to 85% of the corporate share capital of Sole 24 Ore
Formazione. On December 15, 2023, Multiversity acquired 5.379% of the share capital of Materias S.r.l., an
incubator of scientific research activities engaged in identifying innovative ideas in the field of advanced
materials, predominantly generated from the academic sector.

In the 2022/2023 academic year, Multiversity had approximately 206,000 enrolled students, relying on its new
student e-learning platform in order to accommodate its enrolled students across its educational institutions
offering new interactive and effective functionalities based on its experience in education and artificial
intelligence technology spanning over ten years.

**_Online Universities_**

Pegaso is Multiversity’s largest university. Approximately 140,000 students were enrolled in Pegaso’s online
courses for the 2022/2023 academic year. It is the largest single contributor to Multiversity’s results and
accounted for 65.6% (€275.3 million) of Multiversity’s value of production and 73.7% (€182.2 million)[125] of
Multiversity’s Adjusted EBITDA for the year ended December 31, 2023.

Multiversity’s second key institution, Mercatorum, is 66.67% owned by Multiversity, with the remaining
33.33% stake held by Unioncamere, the Italian Union of Chambers of Commerce, Industry, Crafts and
Agriculture. Approximately 53,000 students were enrolled in Mercatorum for the 2022/2023 academic year.
Mercatorum accounted for 24.3% (€102.2 million) of Multiversity’s value of production and 26.4% (€65.2
million)[126] of its Adjusted EBITDA for the year ended December 31, 2023.

Multiversity’s third primary institution in terms of revenue, San Raffaele became part of the Group in 2022, and
it is wholly owned by Multiversity. San Raffaele had approximately 13,000 students enrolled for the 2022/2023
academic year. San Raffaele accounted for 7.4% (€31.2 million) of Multiversity’s value of production and 5.6%
(€13.9 million)[127] of its Adjusted EBITDA for the year ended December 31, 2023.

For further information on Pegaso, Mercatorum and San Raffaele, see “Business—Overview—Online
_Universities.”_

MED.E.A. – Digital Institution for the Mediterranean, Europe and Africa (“MEDEA”). It provides online
courses and other training activities in English and Italian, and has formed an international network of public

**_Non-academic courses_**

_Sole 24 Ore Formazione_

Sole 24 Ore Formazione accounted for 0.1% (€0.4 million) of Multiversity’s value of production as of
December 31, 2023.

Multiversity (holding a majority stake of 85%) operates Sole 24 Ore Formazione in partnership with Il Sole 24
Ore S.p.A. (holding a minority stake of 15%) to deliver executive master's courses to professionals and young
graduates. The new partnership is based on two distinctive factors. First, a top level academic and scientific
training offer, thanks to the support of the universities that are part of the Group. Second, the presence of the Il
Sole 24 Ore group, one of the leading finance newspapers in Italy, which provides content to readers,
professionals, businesses, and institutions on topics of economics, finance, management, and regulations.

_Aulab S.r.l._

Aulab accounted for 1.0% (€4.0 million) of Multiversity’s value of production as of December 31, 2023.

Multiversity owns 60.61% of Aulab, a leading player in the digital training sector for developers with a high
placement rate of its students thanks to an effective training model, an efficient placement platform and
partnerships with top companies. In addition to training, Aulab also designs and develops websites, IT platforms
and software applications.

**_Certifications_**

_Certipass_

Certipass is a provider of international certifications for digital and IT skills known as “EIPASS.” EIPASS, the
European Informatics Passport, is a program for the certification of digital competences in line with European
standards, recognized throughout Europe. All EIPASS certificates are devised with common standards at an
international level, which is necessary for the recognition of the digital certificate in different countries and is of
significant use to companies requiring qualified personnel. Certipass is recognized and accredited by the MIUR
both in Italy and the rest of the EU.

Certipass accounted for 1.3% (€5.4 million) of Multiversity’s value of production as of December 31, 2023.

_Language Certifications_

Through its language center, Pegaso offers a number of language certifications, most prominently the English
Lion Certification (“ELC”). The ELC is a B2 level language certification created and delivered exclusively by
Pegaso, inspired by the principles set forth by the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages
(CEFR). Pegaso is the first online university in Italy to have created its own language certification. The ELC is
an officially recognized certification under the Italian education framework, pursuant to Ministerial Decree no.
353 of May 23, 2014.

**_Academies, Partnerships and Other Assets_**

Pegaso, Mercatorum and San Raffaele have established a number of specialized academies and partnerships in
collaboration with their business partners, such as Principe di Napoli. Multiversity is also developing further
partnerships and academies as part of its strategy to form close relationships with employers with the aim of
developing skills in various vertical sectors through its unique teaching methods.


-----

Additionally, in December 2023, Multiversity acquired a minority stake in Materias S.r.l., an incubator of
scientific research activities engaged in identifying innovative ideas in the field of advanced materials, primarily
generated from the academic sector.

**Offering**

Multiversity’s core offerings, which make up its largest revenue share and student base, are its undergraduate

**_Pegaso International_**

Pegaso International offers four bachelor’s degrees and two Masters of Science in the areas of Business
Administration, Civil Engineering, Education Sciences, and Sport Science, Informatics and Sustainable
Development, and a Ph.D. program in Sustainable Development.

For the 2022/2023 academic year, 81 students were enrolled in Pegaso International (64 in undergraduate
courses and 17 in postgraduate and language courses).

_Ancillary Services_

Various other services are offered to the undergraduate and postgraduate students of Pegaso, Mercatorum and
San Raffaele for additional fees, which mainly relate to certificates and supplemental diplomas.

_Learning Method_

Multiversity’s e-learning institutions’ educational methods involve setting learning objectives (units of learning
content) that are to be achieved through a multitude of tools, materials and services. For each video class, these
are:

- the written core text of the lecture, with bibliographical references and notes;

- slides (supplemented with text, tables, images, graphs) with audio commentary by the lecturer;

- video recordings of the lessons, available to view in either real-time or subsequently at any other time
on the online platform; and

- self-assessment exercises to evaluate the student’s progress.

Final examinations take place at Multiversity’s examination centers throughout Italy (or, in the case of Pegaso
International, Malta) and are overseen by a commission appointed by the rector and chaired by a university
professor.

In order to complete a specific course, students are required to:

- carry out a number of interim assessments (on-line tests to verify learning stages, development of
papers, any laboratory activities, etc.);

- view at least 80% of the online lessons available on the platform; and

- pass the final examination, to be taken in person at the university facilities.


-----

Within each course, students are subject, for each discipline, to interim assessments which are compulsory but
not a prerequisite to qualify for the final examination, in order to constantly monitor learning levels. The
assessments may consist of tests (closed-answer, open-answer, multiple-choice, etc.), exercises, simulations or
group projects.

_Credit and qualification frameworks_

Pegaso’s, Mercatorum’s and San Raffaele’s undergraduate courses confer the qualifications provided for under
the Italian Qualifications Framework, as established by the MIUR in accordance with the Qualifications
Framework for the European Higher Education Area.

The European Credit Transfer System (“ECTS”), an EU-wide education metric aimed at making studies and
courses more transparent, applies to the courses offered at Multiversity’s core institutions. This allows students
to move between countries to obtain their academic qualifications and study periods abroad which are
recognized by allowing credits taken at one higher educational institution to be counted towards a qualification
acquired at another educational institution. One CFU is equivalent to one ECTS credit and students must cover
approximately one third of studies online in order to meet the requirements to pass the examinations

Pegaso International’s courses provide qualifications recognized under the ECTS system, applied within the
European Qualification Framework (“EQF”). The EQF is an eight-level learning outcomes-based framework
for all types of qualifications that serves as a harmonization tool between different national qualifications
frameworks. This framework helps improve transparency, comparability and portability of qualifications and
makes it possible to compare qualifications from different countries and institutions. The EQF covers all types
and all levels of qualifications and the use of learning outcomes to acknowledge the actual skills and
qualifications of individuals. The level increases according to the level of proficiency, level 1 being the lowest
and level 8 the highest. Courses offered by Pegaso International are EQF level 6 or level 7. The EQF is closely
linked to national qualifications frameworks, thereby providing a comprehensive map of all types and levels of
qualifications in Europe, which are increasingly accessible through qualification databases.

_Quality assurance_

In order to ensure the professionalism and quality of degree courses, the MIUR conducts quality assessments
through ANVUR, which is vested with the authority to, among other things, evaluate procedures, results and
outputs of institutions’ management, teaching, research and technological transfer activities, and conduct the
rankings of merit and prestige of both traditional and online universities. The assignment of such rankings is a
legal requirement for the operation of (i) universities offering at least 30% of courses as distance learning
courses or (ii) online universities, which are both scored on a scale from A-tel (very positive) to E-tel
(unsatisfactory), with the consequential closure of the online delivery platform in the event of a negative
outcome.

In its most recent research quality evaluation, the commission of experts appointed by ANVUR assigned a Level
C-tel score to Pegaso, Mercatorum and San Raffaele, corresponding to a satisfactory grade in accordance with
applicable Italian regulations. The next quality evaluation will be conducted in 2024 for San Raffaele and in
2025 for Pegaso and Mercatorum.

The periodic accreditation assessments are processed following on-site visits to the universities by the
commission appointed by ANVUR. The periodic accreditation visits are carried out in three phases: (i) a remote
examination of the documentation made available by the university to the commission, (ii) the actual on-site
visit in order to examine the degree programs and the departments selected by ANVUR for each university and
(iii) the drafting of a report by the commission. See “Regulation” below.

MEDEA, as a provider authorized to deliver courses of study under Pegaso International with MFHEA
(formerly NCFHE) License n.2006-001, is required to ensure compliance with the ten standards of quality
assurance established by the MFHEA in the performance of its internal administrative and teaching procedures.
On November 28, 2023, following the successful outcome of the quality assurance requirements audit
performed by the MFHEA on November 6 and 7, 2023, MEDEA was awarded with the Higher Education
Institute indefinite status licence.

For further information on the quality assurance framework to which the universities of Multiversity are subject.
See “Regulation” below.


-----

_Performance monitoring systems for academic staff_

Although there is no requirement under the applicable Italian legislative framework to monitor the performance
of academic staff in private universities, Pegaso, Mercatorum and San Raffaele have established the respective
procedures, as indicated in the “Quality Assurance” section of their respective websites. There are also models
for evaluation of professors by students (required by ANVUR) which are carried out periodically. The
performance of university professors is also evaluated on the number of academic papers published by them (i.e.
on the basis of their personal research track record).

Professors are contractually required to ensure their course materials remain up to date and the majority of the
materials are updated on a rolling basis, while a full content update is required every three years.

See “—Employment—Faculty training and development” below.

**Research**

**_General_**

In line with the general principles set out in its articles of association, the universities of Multiversity (Pegaso,
San Raffaele and Mercatorum) promote the international development of teaching, research and studies, in
particular through cultural exchange between countries and by instituting collaborations with the most
prestigious universities in the EU.

Grants and research projects contributed to approximately 1% of Multiversity’s revenues for the year ended
December 31, 2023.

**_Benecon_**

In accordance with its corporate mission, Benecon carries out scientific research into airborne sensors,
specifically aircraft that are designed to perform aerial remote sensing actions thanks to hyperspectral, thermal,
photographic sensors developed by Benecon for the monitoring of environmental matrices (air-land-water). Two
researchers from Benecon’s 15-member team are from Pegaso.

Benecon is sponsored by UNESCO and therefore participates in its international research projects in
conjunction with other UNESCO partners.

**_Preferential and corporate rates_**

Pegaso, Multiversity and San Raffaele have in place over 1,000 commercial agreements as of December 31,
2023, securing captive customers which provide for the application of corporate rates for undergraduate and
postgraduate degree courses. The majority of these provide for the application of a reduced tuition fee with
respect to the full tuition fee.

The vast majority of students enrolled at Pegaso, Mercatorum and San Raffaele are entitled to the application of
reduced corporate rates under such agreements, a strong indication that the volume and geographic distribution
of Multiversity’s commercial partnerships across the Italian territory, coupled with the appeal of an innovative
and flexible training method, is key to Multiversity’s business strategy. These rates may apply to specific
degrees, master’s or higher education courses, and in some cases may also apply to certain categories of students
– for example, new graduates or pregnant women, in order to render the course offering more attractive to such
groups. For courses that last more than one year, the preferential tuition fee will apply for each year of the
course.

**_Student funding_**

Tuition fees paid to Multiversity are in the majority of cases funded by the students themselves, with the very
rare use of scholarships. There are no instances of payment by employers on behalf of their employees, nor of
students benefiting from government loans.

In respect of undergraduate courses and academic master’s degrees, payment of tuition fees is due in four equal
installments payable in November, May, June and July of each academic year. The tuition fees for postgraduate
master’s courses and single courses are paid as a lump sum payment.

**_Remuneration of Professors and Researchers_**

The Italian national legislative framework on the remuneration of professors, which sets out in specific tables
the range of wages payable to tenured professors and associate professors at all universities across the country
(such wages varying on the grade of professor and based on whether the professors are permanent professors[140]
or full term professors[141], provided that both tenured professors and associate professors are employed under
permanent contracts) and researchers, which are instead employed on fixed term contracts. Such statutory
provisions apply to all universities, with no distinction between public or private, “traditional” or online
universities. The level of remuneration applicable to the relevant professor within the ranges specific above will
depend on the grade of such professor. Following an assessment of the relevant professor’s scientific production
(e.g., research activities, publications, etc.) and a formal evaluation based on criteria regulated by law, tenured
and associate professors may progress to a higher grade every three years, thereby becoming entitled to the next
level of remuneration.

Researchers have temporary contracts that may be a: (a) six-year contract, with the possibility of a single twoyear extension, based on an assessment of the educational and research activities carried out; or (b) six-year
contract without possibility of extension.[142]Remuneration due to researchers under (b) above may be increased
up to a maximum of 30%.

**_Stock option plan and incentives_**

At its meeting held on May 27, 2021, the Board of Directors of Multiversity approved a stock option plan
comprising 1000 options with regard to the shares of Multiversity S.r.l. (the “Plan”) for the benefit of directors,
employees and/or collaborators of the Group and its subsidiaries to be identified by the Board of Directors from
time to time.

The Multiversity shareholders’ meeting of June 23, 2021 approved a non-proportional share capital increase by
a nominal amount equal to €1,000 in favor of some key managers of the Group, who have been assigned the
option rights to subscribe the capital increase once some relevant conditions are met. The stock options
conferred pursuant to the Plan can be exercised upon the occurrence of certain events and subject to certain
conditions. Since the key conditions are not met at the time of preparation of the Consolidated Financial
Statements, the share capital was not subscribed. Such new shares are reserved for subscription within the final
deadline of December 31, 2035.

The key managers of the Group, as approved by the Board of Directors meeting held in February 2021, are
attributed a bonus if some key parameters, in terms of Group and individual economic performance are met,
based on the year end results. An estimate of year-end bonuses is accrued in the Consolidated Financial
Statements.

_Faculty retention and churn rates_

The associate or tenured professors of Pegaso, Mercatorum or San Raffaele that were originally in the
organization have rarely left the Multiversity educational institutions voluntarily. In certain instances, faculty
staff employed on temporary contracts have been offered positions elsewhere. Professors that are not tenured are
engaged through fixed term contracts, which are renewed on an annual basis. Many junior professors are
employed as researchers on fixed term contracts and are subsequently employed indefinitely after winning
tenure as associates.

Researchers are offered a six-year contract that may be extended by the institution for a further two years if their
research meets certain criteria.

As part of Multiversity’s talent retention strategy, temporary personnel that qualify for associate professorship
typically commence the process of becoming tenured professors within approximately four months.

_Faculty training and development_

Pegaso has opened a Teaching and Learning Center dedicated to the training of faculty members with a
particular focus on remote learning techniques. Mandatory training courses are also made available to professors
on the e- learning platform (e.g. techniques/guides for organizing materials, courses on interactive teaching) and
training for tutors (led by more experienced tutors and professors).

The same applies to Mercatorum where given the university’s assistance to the Italian chambers of commerce,
focus groups also are established to monitor and study legislative developments that are relevant to the
chambers of commerce.

With a view to attracting talent, the Boards of Directors of the three universities consider all faculty who have
passed into the first rank for the role of full professor, which is an uncommon practice in the industry.

**Technology Platform**

The e-learning platform utilized by Pegaso, Mercatorum and San Raffaele, which is proprietary and owned by
Multiversity[143], was among the first e-learning platforms in Italy to be run through mobile applications,
combining innovative technology with modern e-learning methods. Key characteristics of the platform are the
following:

- the platform may be run from any device, including iOS and Android;

- student-friendly and accessible 24 hours a day;

- allows immediate access to the entire online university educational offering;

- creates and encourages student community in an online hub, aimed at team building and the stimulation
of ideas for the creation of new businesses; and

- contains interactive modules with innovative live-chat technology including multichannel chat systems,

Students can watch lessons, access class materials and thematic blogs, interact with professors and tutors,
participate with other students in the social community.

Course content is prepared by academic staff, with the support of Multiversity IT staff who, among other things,
professionally edit files and enable their delivery across all e-learning platforms. All original course content is
owned by the relevant institutions of Multiversity.

Certipass uses only a small part of the Multiversity e-learning platform, as it has developed its own proprietary
platform which is used solely for the assessments required to grant the EIPASS certifications. Certipass uses the
same cybersecurity and data protection systems as Multiversity.

**_Core systems_**

Multiversity has continuously invested in its IT platform and systems from its inception in order to deliver the
highest quality online learning platform.

The platform is entirely owned by Multiversity. The e-learning platforms and core systems are developed fully
in-house, originally leveraging an open-source software that was customized to develop a unique proprietary
platform. Since 2017, the platform has been run and stored on servers hosted by AWS cloud data centers to
maximize efficiency, with horizontal and physical back-up for disaster recovery. A backup copy of the stored
data is kept at the data center at Pegaso’s headquarters in Naples, which is activated in the event of disaster
recovery to ensure zero time loss of service. The current package contracted with AWS is for 150
terabyte/month of data storage and relies on a multi-server system, with a load balancer to manage user traffic
overload.

Multiversity leverages on a proprietary and in-house developed technology platform and ensures high scalability
and an excellent student experience, thanks to a personalized student dashboard which allows maximization of
the learning potential and tracks progress of the didactic path. Through the use of cookies and app tracking,
personalized content is provided to users with respect to their university career, including suggestions for
postgraduate pathways and invitations to continue studying if certain academic targets are reached.

Multiversity’s IT team, which includes software developers, content production and IT Infrastructure personnel,
is currently composed of 49 employees.

A new web version of the platform was launched over the summer of 2021, incorporating several updates
including a new design, more interactive interface and other user experience improvements.

_Artificial Intelligence and Machine Learning_

Multiversity has developed a multi-year plan which addresses the opportunities that AI and ML offers to
improve students’ learning experience and increase operational efficiency, and is ideally positioned to leverage
AI tools and successfully compete with other higher education institutions in Italy and Europe. Through this
multi-year plan Multiversity already developed two products: (i) an AI University Assistant Tool that leverages
OpenAI to provide students with 24/7 support through a chatbot exclusively trained with specific course content
selected by professors, and (ii) a technology/administrative chatbot for customer care that leverages Amazon
Bedrock.

In particular, the AI University Assistant tool is seen as one of the most advanced ones in its field globally,
providing answers with an over 99% accuracy. This performance is continuously tracked through a dedicated
multi-level monitoring team. Multiversity reviews the global market for AI-based solutions in education on a
weekly basis through a strategic observatory, which continuously monitors any potential developments along
with any risks and opportunities in the education space. These potential opportunities primarily include new
learning formats (such as virtual laboratories and tutoring chatbots), new topics to be taught to address the
growing demand for AI roles in the job market, and the automatization of support services.

_Evaluation and compliance of IT platform_

Pegaso, Mercatorum and San Raffaele must meet legal requirements, which are reviewed by the ANVUR
Evaluation Committee every five years. Pegaso and Mercatorum scored high rankings/ratings with respect to the
technology used during the last evaluation in October 2017.

Under the previous legislative framework, periodic evaluations needed to be carried out every five years through
a five-day site visit by the ANVUR Evaluation Committee. Pegaso obtained the highest rating among online
universities during the last periodic evaluation and on that basis the site visit (which would be necessary in case
of an insufficient rating) is no longer required. As a result, it is sufficient to provide a report to the ANVUR
Evaluation Committee. The most recent report was provided to the ANVUR Evaluation Committee on June 30,

_Cybersecurity and data protection_

Multiversity has established and maintains cybersecurity systems that are developed and updated internally,
including a monitoring system that monitors the platform and code transactions on it. The cloud data centers are
only accessible through Pegaso’s headquarters in Naples, by authorized members of the IT team through a twotier security system. In particular, Multiversity employs a cybersecurity program leased from Amazon in order
to protect against the risk of DDoS[144] cyber-attacks.

Users’ passwords are tokenized; access to servers is allowed only through the network and firewalls present at
the business center at Muliversity’s headquarters. Access to all externally-facing applications is protected by a
web application firewall and users are required to register and create a personal profile accessible through a
username and password, which is encrypted and tokenized, ensuring that the specific user may only view areas
within the application to which it has been granted access. In addition, a secure hash algorithm protects users’

144 ‘Denial of Service’ cyber attacks in which the perpetrator seeks to make a machine or network resource unavailable to its
intended users by temporarily or indefinitely disrupting services of a host connected to the Internet.


-----

stored credentials on the server side. The security measures adopted under the platform ensure protection of
user’s personal data in compliance with the GDPR and Multiversity provides information to its employees on an
annual basis as to the data protection measures that need to be put in place. Multiversity has procedures in place
for data collection and processing in accordance with the GDPR and Italian applicable law (including in order to
ensure that any revocation of permission by users to process their personal data is actioned within 24 hours).

In terms of client/server side security, the devices used by the students and academic staff are separate and there
is no direct client-side access to the servers.

In terms of protection against data loss, a back-up copy of stored data is accessible from the data center at
Pegaso’s headquarters in Naples and is activated in the event of disaster recovery to ensure zero time loss of
service. In the event of a system memory overload, temporary servers are created ensuring sufficient system
memory/CPU to run the platform. Through the use of this system, the platform does not have a limit to the
maximum number of users that may access it simultaneously.

Multiversity carries out penetration tests internally every time a new IT procedure is created, and risk
assessments are also carried out on an annual basis and in conjunction with any penetration test. Additionally, a
detailed risk assessment on AI adoption, which includes legal, privacy technical and sustainability
considerations and involves a data scientist expert in ML, is conducted by Multiversity every time a new AI
initiative is launched.

**Sustainability**

**_Sustainable Development Goals (“SDGs”)_**

Achieving inclusive and quality education for all people reaffirms the belief that education is one of the most
powerful and proven vehicles for sustainable development. The SDGs initiative established by the UN aims to
provide equal access to affordable vocational training, eliminate gender and wealth disparities and achieve
universal access to a quality higher education by 2030.

In line with the SDGs, Multiversity remains loyal to its commitment to ensure an inclusive and fair quality
education, to promote opportunities of continuous learning for everyone and a sustainable and inclusive
economic growth, facilitating access to honourable job opportunities for everyone. In this context, the online
education has no geographical barriers, flexible and democratic approach and can play a relevant role to attain
some of the main goals of the 2030 SDG agenda.

In addition to its compliance with relevant laws and regulations in relation to ESG and sustainability,
Multiversity approved an ESG strategic plan in June 2023 based on five pillars: (i) innovative, accessible and
quality education, (ii) a healthy work environment that promotes inclusion and diversity, (iii) protection of our
planet, (iv) community engagement, and (v) good governance.

Furthermore, in 2023, Multiversity received the EcoVadis gold medal for sustainability (ranking in the top 5%
globally) and a 7.8 ESG rating from Sustainalytics (ranking in the top 2% globally). In the same year,
Multiversity also achieved significant results in low scope 1 & 2 CO2 emissions (0.005 tCO2e per student and
1.44 tCO2e per employee), and holds key sustainability certifications such as ISO 9001 (quality management
systems) and ISO 14001 (environmental management systems).
